  2419. But then I noticed I had a lot less razor burn than before and more importantly, less tugging at my longer hairs.
  2420. Norelco shaving heads flex to the contours of your face or neck; this model has greater range of movement with less pressure required than previous models.
  2421. Mine shaves closer in less time, recharges in half the time, more sturdy, sliding on/off button.
  2422. This particular Speed replaced a base-model, roughly 4-year old Quadra.....
  2423. I bought this to replace an older shaver in the same line that I had used for over ten years.
  2424. It charges very fast, and does not need a bulky stand which I hate very much, and it is not trivial in bathroom as too many charge stations are already there.
  2425. Maybe it's got something to do with the way they redesigned the combs with all the added little holes instead of full, open combs all the way around each cutter.
  2426. Generally I like this unit.
  2427. Thoughts:<br />Despite my general satisfaction with this shaver, I have decided it's time to upgrade.
  2428. and I find the 2 razors generally equivalent.
  2429. The 8240 shaves AT LEAST as close and comfortable as the 3-D, if not
  2430. I am probably average as far as hair and skin sensitivity, don't move over skin too fast and finish before the blades heat up

  2542. This particular model does not have a charge indicator to let you know when it will need to be charged, so it just stops abruptly.
  2543.   2544. Other than that I would highly recommend this shaver.
  2545. though much lighter than my old unit; * wish case had a small pocket for the cleaning brush;
  2546. do, however, have to register a minor complaint, and it is that Norelco saw fit to leave out low-battery warning lights.
  2547. I can not feel anything at all while shaving and my 8240 shaver seems much quieter and smoother than my previous 6615 shaver.
  2548. The pop out trimmer on this model is also wider than my previous model which makes trimming sideburns much easier.
  2549. The speed of this shaver is much slower than my previous one.
  2550. Because of the increased cutting area I think my shaves go slightly more quickly than with my previous 6615 shaver -
  2551. the moment I started using it, my only regret was that I'd waited so long before dumping the old one!<br /><br
  2552. It is not as good at cutting longer hair, and will pull if hair is too long.
  2553. I have a very sensitive skin, when I shave wet
  2554. It does have difficulty shaving the neck and mustache areas, as I have to go over those areas multiple times to cut the hairs down to a reasonable level.
  2555. I'm not sure that I can get the same quick cleaning with this without fatiguing the flip-hinge, and don't think I can do the flat whack on the sink, either.
  2556. It did not seem to measure up to even my old single blade Remington.
  2557. I found the trimmer to be adequate, but not as sharp as the trimmer on my previous 7885XL.
  2558. The ability to wash the shaver down with water is a plus but it does leave a coating of \\"shmutz\\" inside the workings that you'll deal with when you finally break the shaver down to clean the heads and the assembly pieces (which they recommend monthly).
  2559. Of course, blades dull rather quickly, and sometimes requires multiple passes to get patches it missed.
  2560. I managed to squeeze the new shaver and charger into the old (larger) leather case that came with my previous Norelco model - a tight fit (previous models had only a cord, this one has an external transformer).
  2561. It seems less powerful than necessary, and less than my old 6830.
  2562. My original review for this razor was not good, however, now that my skin has gotten used to it, I felt obligated to write another review.
  2563. the price is now in the low 90's, much closer to the typical retail price.....
  2564. I purchased this upgraded Norelco shaver in July, 2010 for a closer shave than I had been getting from lower priced Norelco shavers; but this one is less than a year old and does not cut as close as my old one that I had to get out of the closet to start using again.
  2565. I had previously purchased a Braun which forced me to go over an area many times before all the hairs had been clipped.
  2566. overall, good for not so close shave and probaly not good enough for guys with thick stubble.
  2567. The old single track Philips Norelco I used to have seemed to give me the same shave in a quicker time though.
  2568. If charged, it's very compact and takes little room in a suitcase if you don't need the cord along.
  2569. The only drawback is there is no stand for the razor and the bottom is not flat for it to stand up.
  2570. i figured i'd just buy a new razor since the battery life on my other razor was fading.
  2571. However, if you don't already have an HQ 5 based razor, or yours is dead (aka battery no longer charges) then this is a fine, albeit not fantastic, electric razor.
  2572. The 3 heads, with their contour following system and lift and cut technology really are a little powerhouse.

It is easy to wash out but does not charge well.There is nothing to tell us the charge is finished. I think next time I will get a shaver for him that has a cord to it......
  4. Holds a charge for weeks. By the 3rd time I used it there was no face burn at all.<br />Great product. Replaced my 10 year old shaver that wouldn't hold a charge.<br />The new one cuts so much better and faster.
  5. good product- but lacks a light to inform you to recharge the razor, other styles have this feature.<br />Other than that a good value

  7. Not as good as my original. Not battery indicator. You do not know when the battery is low, or when it is fully charged. For over 200.00 it is shame on Norelco not to have include this standard feature. I would not buy another Norelco product.
  8. I owned a Norelco Rotary Shaver for about 8 years. It was working fine until the rechargeable battery would no longer hold a charge. I would have replaced it myself - but I don't know how to solder, so I broke down and ordered the Braun Series 3 340 foil shaver. I had done a little research and most of the \\"experts\\" all suggested that foil shavers shave closer than rotary shavers. Obviously, razor blades have the \\"closest\\" shave, but I wanted the convenience of an electric shaver. I do not have a thick beard - anything but. I only shave once every 3-4 days so I end up w/ long whiskers in spots vs. 5 o'clock shadow that some people get after an hour :)<br /><br />Anyway, the Braun Series 3 is a beautifully constructed shaver - but it didn't work very well. It took many passes to cut my facial hair...and then I had to work it from different angles to successfully shave off the hair at different parts of my face. Yes, it finally shaved - but it seemed to take so much longer. In the end, I just wasn't impressed at all - so I returned it for a refund.<br /><br />After a week or so, I purchased the Norelco 8240XL rotary shaver. It is not as nice looking as the Braun - and certainly doesn't feel as well constructed - but it shaved me beautifully the first time around. The trimmer works so-so, but I didn't really buy it for the trimmer. The 8240XL cleans easily. The only thing wrong with the 8240XL package is the travel case. The travel case only holds the shaver - and does not allow for the brush and charging cord. How cheap is that? Norelco really should include a larger case to accommodate the cord.<br /><br />I give the 8240 XL 5 stars as a shaver....and 1 star for the case. 4 overall only because the shaver outweighs the case. I'd recommend this product.
  9. The Norelco Shaver was promptly delivered as advertised. The unit is very easy to use and the instructions are clear. Charging is a simple \\"plug it in\\" and go. The overall shave is pretty good and the swivel on the heads makes for a reasonably comfortable shave. The blade height is not adjustable so I find myself making a couple of passes for a really close shave. My previous Norelco, which lasted me ten years, had this feature. Overall this was a very good value and I am pleased so far.
  10. This is my second norelco that I have owned. The previous one worked flawlessly for 7 years until I dropped it on our ceramic tile floor in the bathroom. (not a wise thing to do) I got the 8240XL about three weeks ago and it gave me a close shave right out of the box. I would highly recommend this product because I have a thick beard and if it can shave me close I could imagine what it could do for an average person.
  11. exceptionally quiet. gives a nice close shave. I particularly like the hot water rinsing-cleaning feature.
  12. Battery life is excellent, have used for one month and I'm still on the first charge. Shave is very close, but does not irritate my skin. Performance on my neck is somewhat lacking. I spend 60% of my shave time trying to get my neck finished. In all fairness I have yet to use an electric razor that works the neck area perfectly. Overall, very pleased.
  13. A great razor without a lot of bells and whistles. Why pay 2 or 3 times more for, basically, the same razor with a few more lights? I agree that a low battery light would have been nice, but this isn't a big deal since the battery lasts a long time and can be charged in 1 hour. Plus, if you don't have an hour to wait around a quick 5 minute charge will get the job done (or you can use it corded.) Now, as far as the shave goes it gives a very close shave with no irritation. It is a little faster than previous models but don't expect to cut your shaving time in half. I tried a foil razor once and it left a few stray hairs here and there which it refused to pick up no matter how hard I tried to get them. I switched to a rotary and I haven't had that problem since. I switched to electric razors a few years ago when my face just couldn't handle blades anymore; I thought I'd have to sacrifice the closeness of a blade for a healthier face but this hasn't been the case with Norelco, they have consistently given me blade close shaves. I've had this razor for about 6 months now and couldn't be happier. I've read the reviews on the Arcitec and, honestly, can't see a good reason why I should pay 2 or 3 times for it when this one works so wonderfully.
  14. This is a very nice electric razor for the price. Would definitely buy this from Amazon again!
  15. I've been using Norelco shavers for years. After 4 years of reliable service, my last one finally gave up the ghost and would no longer hold a charge, so I decided it was time for a new shaver. I decided on the 8240XL because of the balance of features it offered and its pricepoint. I could not be happier. There were several things that I noticed when I first started using it. First, I was amazed at how light it was. After using Ni-Cad powered shavers for the past 6 years, I was used to some \\"heft.\\" This shaver on the other hand is powered by a much lighter Li-Ion battery. The second thing I noticed was how long the charge lasted. I got over a weeks worth of shaves off of one charge- again thanks to the Li-Ion battery. The third thing I noticed, like other reviewers, was how quiet it was. It didn't sound like I was holding my buzzing alarm clock next to my face as I shaved. The final feature that I really appreciate on this shaver is the charging time. It will fully recharge in about an hour. But, all these features are pointless if the shaver doesn't do what it was designed to do... shave! The manual stated that it takes about a week or so for your face to adjust to a new shaver, and that was pretty accurate. The first week, it felt \\"funny\\" or \\"different\\" on my face. It provided a good shave, but it just didn't feel like what I was used to. After a week though, that funny feeling went away and the shaver felt very natural. The shave it provides is comfortable and close. It doesn't pull or snag on my longer whiskers. It pivots and glides well across my face and is able to shave close in those areas that are typically hard to get a close shave in. The only thing about this shaver that doesn't thrill me is the lack of a charge indicator. Some of the more expensive models in this lineup have that feature, but I wasn't willing to pay for it, so in some regards I can't complain but so much. On the old Ni-Cad powered shavers, even if the shaver did not have a charge indicator, you could hear and feel the shaver getting slower as the charge died. For this Li-Ion powered shaver, that is not the case. It keeps its power up right until the charge is gone. In some ways that's good because it gives you full power until the end. In other ways it's bad because you don't know when the \\"end\\" is and you could be in the middle of a shave. On the bright side though, it will recharge in an hour (as long as you have the charger with you). Overall, I highly recommend this shaver. It's a full-featured shaver at a reasonable price.
  16. I was always a Norelco user for many years but last year I bought a \\"Braun\\". What a mistake, because when I came back in November, 2009 with your new Norelco 8240XL it was a better product by giving me a closer all around shave. Another factor, when I did not shave after 2-3 days I did not have to use the trimmer to remove the few stray hairs close to my upper lip. I ALWAYS had to use the Braun's trimmer to remove these stray hairs. Last but not least, the cleaning of the blades by using the water faucet is fantastic. The price was also a great buy KUDOS! Ed Olonovich
  17. My husband is thrilled with this shaver that was a Christmas gift. I did a great deal of research before purchasing a new shaver--I was going to get him one of those new, three-floating platform shavers that have become so popular. However, after reading numerous reviews about problems with those shavers (he would hate to have to clean out the shavings chamber every other day, and I was concerned about reports of getting shaving burns), I found this little gem with great reviews. A no-frills shaver (which suits my husband), the price was just right, and he is surprised at the quality of his shave, the speed of the shave, and how quietly it works. I did just fine with this gift!
  18. The Norelco 8240 offers the best value/comfort/performance for the money I've found. Lower models in the Norelco line lack some very effective features (floating heads, multiple inset rotary heads, etc.), while higher models are much more expensive with no benefit to performance (some do a poorer job of shaving, including the ARC series).<br /><br />Although the best foil shavers generally shave closer, the Norelco 8240 cuts nearly as close (not quite, but the difference is virtually unnoticeable). The rotary heads, however, are MUCH more comfortable and not nearly as prone to razorburn as foil shavers. The floating heads on this model are excellent (not as stiff and MORE effective than the $130 ARC series), conforming well to my face, even at my sharp chin and gentle adam's apple.<br /><br />Here is what makes it really superb compared to any other shaver I've tried in my 18 years of shaving:<br /><br />- The $80 price (at Walmart, December 2009), on the low end of the price range that consistently offers the best value/performance ratio ($70 - $110).<br /><br />- The motor is wonderfully quiet... it purs in a low, comforting tone, without the high whine of most other rotary and foil razors I've tried (the ARC series is much louder, as are Braun foil shavers). When I first used it, I though the battery must be low on charge, but I finally realized that it really is just that quiet all the time.<br /><br />- The shaving performance is excellent: It offers the 2nd closest shave I've had from an electric shaver (The Braun foil shaver I've used for the last 6 years shaves negligibly closer), yet gives almost zero razorburn to my sensitive/dry skin (the Braun gave mild to moderate razorburn daily). Better yet, the Norelco shaves close WITHOUT need to pull my skin tight with a second hand as I shave. That is the main reason I switched back to rotary... Foil shavers only give a close shave by constantly pulling the facial skin tight with another hand while shaving.<br /><br />- The ergonomics are very comfortable: It fits perfectly in my hand and feels very light. My Braun foil shaver always felt like holding a large cell phone... no ergonomics to speak of, which occasionally led to dropping it.<br /><br />I'm convinced that negative reviews of this razor are either by folks with very strange face shapes or, more likely, folks who don't understand that a razor MUST BE BROKEN IN for about two weeks before it offers an optimum shave. On the first shave, the Norelco 8240 is unimpressive, but by the fifth or sixth morning (assuming you use it exclusively), it will adjust to your face and give you a remarkably good shave. The quality continues to improve slightly until about the end of the second week. Stick with it, and you'll be glad.br />- The ergonomics are very comfortable: It fits perfectly in my hand and feels very light. My Braun foil shaver always felt like holding a large cell phone... no ergonomics to speak of, which occasionally led to dropping it.<br /><br />I'm convinced that negative reviews of this razor are either by folks with very strange face shapes or, more likely, folks who don't understand that a razor MUST BE BROKEN IN for about two weeks before it offers an optimum shave. On the first shave, the Norelco 8240 is unimpressive, but by the fifth or sixth morning (assuming you use it exclusively), it will adjust to your face and give you a remarkably good shave. The quality continues to improve slightly until about the end of the second week. Stick with it, and you'll be glad.

  20. I've never owned an electric shaver and remember the ancient ones my father had ages ago and was never interested in them as they never seemed to give a decent shave. A friend of mine has one of these and uses it for his head and that seemed like something that would work for me since I have the same haircut and shaving with a razor can be a pita at times compared to running this around your head! He also said that the Norelco was better than the Braun units (for your head), I'd guess because of the three floating heads ability to deal with all the contours. I am impressed with the Norelco's performance, it does exactly what I want it to do for my head and now and then I'll use it for my face too and it seems to work pretty well there. I still prefer a razor for my face and neck, I don't think anything comes close but this works good on the face too and average on the neck. Briefly I'd rate it as: Head=great, Face=pretty damn good, Neck=average.
  21. I have always used a foil razor and when my old one died, I thought I would give a rotary a chance. I did use the product for 3 weeks to \\"let my skin adjust\\", but even from the first shave, the motor seemed underpowered and seemed to take twice as long to shave. I also prefer a foil to do the jaw line and more angled areas. I traded it in for the 45-day trial and got a Panasonic 8243 which I am stoked about.
  22. Rotary razor technology has not changed fundamentally in fifty years -- and foil technology hasn't in seventy -- but the razors get slowly better with newer materials and tinkering. This is as good as rotaries get at the moment; the newer, narrower Norelco models shave no closer and are louder. No electric shaves as well as a blade but this comes surprisingly close, at least for men with rotary faces (some do better with foil razors). As other reviews have mentioned, when the charge runs out it stops suddenly without any audible warning. But that doesn't happen very often, and when it does you just plug it in; the razor will work immediately.
  23. I have always owned Norelco shavers but unfortunately this is not one of my favorites. Due to the design for the pivoting razor head assembly it allows shaven hair to fall out of the shaver while shaving. All my past shavers had enclosed main heads with the individual floating heads which contained the shaven hair until rinsed. Still does a good job of shaving but is slightly on the messy side.
  24. I've used the standard gel and razor for shaving till now and thought of trying out the electric shaver. The shave did seem to be close, but with this shaver, you pretty much shave against the grain. If you do that with a regular razor, you can probably get an even better shave. Against the grain did not work well for me.<br /><br />3. I had to spend some time shaving with this. It didnt seem powerful enough to shave the hair off in one go. It took me multiple passes.<br /><br />4. The shave was even worse around the jaw line and on the neck and hence it took even more passes, resulting in more abrasion on the skin.<br /><br />Overall, I'm not happy with the product and will return it.

I do clean it after each use, as per their instructions and take out the razor heads once per month and wash them under hot water.

  33. I always used to think that Norelco was the Cadillac (Mercedes?) of electric shavers. Same thing happened to the replacement within six months. I guess that's why they pulled it off the market quickly. I wasn't going to buy Norelco again, but I was swayed by all the reviews here. I bought the 8240 almost exactly a year ago from Amazon (and for $69.99). No real complaints for a year. Just a little hard to shave up near the nostrils. Easy to clean, a big plus with me. Unfortunately the day came when I forgot to stop charging it after an hour and left it to charge all night. Next morning it ran for 15 seconds and quit cold. Now the battery won't hold a charge at all no matter how long or short you charge it. I haven't given up on it yet, but for now I have a corded razor. Addendum - 1 month later: Could not resuscitate the battery. Nice shaver still, but corded.

  37. Gives a very close shave - practically as close as a blade. The only issue is one that applies to all electric shavers - your face must be absolutely clean & dry for the shaver to work. The slightest bit of moisture, perspiration, etc. will cause the unit to skip areas. This particular model does not have a charge indicator to let you know when it will need to be charged, so it just stops abruptly. That's not a major problem because it can be used as a corded shaver & the charge time is very fast - around an hour.

  59. I only gave this product four stars because I've only used it for one week, but so far I'm really enjoying it! Sure, after 25 years of shaving with blades I'm bound to have some irritation. All my research indicated that it would take my skin and beard 3-4 weeks to adjust, but so far my irritation is confined to the area above my upper lip and below my lower lip. I bought this item at Amazon.com for an amazing $69.99...whereas the local Walmart sold it for $93.00. At first the shave wasn't as close as I'd expected, but the more you use the razor the closer the shave gets. I'm a military officer and after just one week it gives me a shave close enough for any inspection. It's quiet, smooth, easy-to-use, and easy-to-clean. Save yourself the extra $30 for the cleaning & charging stand that comes with the 8260 Speed XL...all you need to do is rinse under hot tap water daily and give it a more thorough cleaning each month. Also get yourself some cleaner/lubricant for electric razors (Remington Shaver Saver). I recommend that those that are new to electric shaving follow all the recommended steps below until your skin fully transitions to electric shavers: - Shave after you shower with hot water and wash your face thoroughly. Use a good face scrub every other day to exfoliate dead skin and prevent ingrown hairs (recommend Neutrogena Razor Defense, Every Man Jack, or Nivea). - Use a pre-electric shave lotion like William's Lectric Shave to dry out the hairs and help them stick out straight (it really does help though it smells strong!). - Spray your razor heads with Remington Shaver Saver before each use to lubricate the blades and help reduce friction (saves your face and razor at the same time). - As soon as you're done shaving, rinse your face well with COLD water and apply a good, soothing after shave balm/lotion/gel. Go for one of the new brands with low alcohol content and high contents of glycerin, aloe, etc. Again, recommendedbrands are Neutrogena Razor Defense, Every Man Jack Cooling Gel, or Nivea. Don't give in and quit before your 3-4 week transition period is over...stick with it and you will soon enjoy the convenience and cost savings of electric shaving. I will continue this review after another month or so. Good luck!
  60. I have been using Norelco Rotary shavers since I started shaving 30+ years ago. Other methods always irritated my skin but he Norelco's rarely did. This one is so much quieter and lighter than any of the ones I've had before. You can actually hear what's going on around you.

Right out of the box, the Norelco shaved so close, I would have sworn I had shaved with a straight razor. I will never go back to a Braun.   62. Nice shave and easy cleanup quick recharge As advertised, no low battery indicator however
  63. I found this Electric Razor to be exactly what I was looking for. Very happy with it. Easy to use and maintain
  64. Overall, I'm quite satisfied with my model 8240XL. I actually \\"downgraded\\" from an Arcitec model because I'm mostly bald and also shave the top of my head, but the loud Arcitec caused scrapes on top of my head that would scab up. Also, the small Arcitec trimmer was too short and imprecise for trimming the sideburns and the shaving head gets in the way of positioning this trimmer. Further, the Arcitec heads are impossible to take apart and clean thoroughly, so the heads would clog up with long hairs which took many tedious minutes to clean out with sharp tweezers! The 8240XL provides relief from the above problems, giving a great shave, and the pitch and sound volume is surprisingly lower in a small bathroom. My only concern is the manual gave no indication how this \\"low-end\\" model, without a low battery LED, notifies the user of low battery charge. The answer is not that it simply slows down like a rubber band glider, but that it simply stops abruptly in the middle of a shave. The first time, I thought it was broken! To my delight, it resurrected after charging for a few hours. So, the moral is to always keep that charge cord handy. I know Norelco may love to charge $20-$30 more for the upgrade model, but this is really a bit cheap on their part for what must be the tiny expense of adding the low battery LED to all models.
  65. Good product - I replaced my old Phillips with this one and am very satisfied.
  66. -- Gives a decent, reasonably fast shave on one- or two-day beards,not so much for longer ones -- normal for Norelcos. -- Cleans up well under a stream of hot tap water. :) -- Head is very prone to popping open while shaving, with only a light touch needed to dump nano-fibers of hair inside your shirt :( -- Charging process calls for you to unplug the shaver once full charge is reached, or the battery degrades faster. Means you have to monitor it rather than set it & forget it. :| -- Charging light is reversed in my view -- is solid when charging, blinks when 'full'. I think it'd be better to reverse this. Oh Well. :| -- You've gotta hold your mouth right to get the shaver head back into the hinge keeper after you remove it for detailed head cleaning. :( -- Shaver end of the charging cord is all black, as is the plug end of the shaver. In any case, there's no easy visual indicator whether the slot in the plug should face up or down, and which side of the shaver is up or down. :! All in all, probably a case of design by bean counter.

I just wish that there was a better packaging system than the plastic bubble packs. You have to take care not to slit your wrists when trying to cut through them.

  71. I paid $93+ for this puppy at Target a few months ago. It feels well made. The shavers in the $50 range feel / look like junk. I'm not sure if one shaver shaves any better than the other. They all have blades that go round and round or back and forth. The charge does seem to last longer than other shavers I've had. But it gives no warning as to when the charge is gone, it just stops dead... But hey, it's not made in China ! I was stunned to see it was made in the Netherlands !
  72. My 8240XL arrived from Amazon 5/21/2010 by USPS. I ordered it 5/16/2010 and requested \\"Super Saver\\" free shipping so it took a few days. The shaver, shaving head protector, manuals, soft carrying case and brush were all present (nothing missing) and were all in good shape. I am not happy with Amazon reducing the price of my 8240 by $3.00 only 2 days after I placed my order. I realize that's how buying on the Internet works but it doesn't make me feel any better. I'm certainly not pleased with Amazon for doing this and not automatically giving me a break. I should have heeded the recommendations in an appraisal I read prior to attempting to open the plastic blister pack. I should have used my large tin snips instead of a standard scissors for cutting off the plastic lip. It was difficult to do with a standard scissors. I slipped once and bloodied my thumb as a result (the back side of my thumb rammed into a cut surface of the plastic lip which was rather sharp). This is my major complaint about this shaver - it seems Norelco could come up with something a bit easier, not to mention safer, for the average customer to open. I initially charged the batteries for about 13 hours (manual recommends 12 hours - I didn't awaken soon enough very early in the morning). Although I don't understand why the initial 12 hour charge is recommended since the battery showed full charge (led started blinking) after approximately 1 hour, however, I could see no harm in leaving the shaver attached to the charger for the recommended time. I think the perceived instruction manual contradiction of recommending the 12 hour initial charge vs. subsequently not continuously charging does not apply for the 1st charge. I think the manual is recommending the user not recharge the unit until the batteries are run down and this does not apply to the initial charge procedure. I have done my own evaluations of NiCad batteries as part of my former job at Schick (New Product Development Lab back in the 1970s) and they work best, not to mention last the longest, when they are always nearly completely discharged before recharging. This is what I have done with my most recent Norelco, model 6615X (cordless only) and its NiCad batteries are still OK after about 6½ years continuous use. NiCad batteries tend to develop a \\"memory\\" if they are recharged too soon, too frequently or continuously and will prematurely lose their charge holding capability. I miss the low battery indicator that was on my old 955RX Norelco shaver. This had an LCD bar display showing various charge levels. With this indicator I would have an idea when the batteries were almost discharged so I would not be unexpectedly surprised in the middle of a shave. My experience with my previous 'cordless only' Norelco (6615X) has been a problem when it would stop in the middle of a shave. I would then need to shift to my old 955RX (cord and cordless) to finish the shave. The new 8240's batteries finally ran down after a month of daily use. No warning, I heard a click and it just stopped. I plugged in the power cord and finished shaving with no problem. It took about an hour to recharge afterwards. I do not understand how a previous user had all shaving head parts fly out when he popped open the head for cleaning. They are retained by a traditional Norelco retention system which has always worked well for me. The components should not come loose unless improperly assembled. I suppose it's possible the factory did something wrong in this person's case, however, I have had no problem when I daily pop the head open for rinsing under hot water. Nothing has come apart; nothing is loose or assembled improperly. The head popped open easily by pushing the little button under it and it was quite easy to rinse out the debris using hot water as the manual recommends. After one month I disassembled the head and cleaned the comb assembly components in alcohol. No problem but it'sa very delicate operation and it is very easy to damage the components. The manual recommends doing this monthly. Too bad Norelco can't come up with a design that doesn't require disassembly of the shaving head for monthly cleaning. Good for business I suppose - probably sells lots of replacement comb/cutter assemblies. I have a concern about the manual's recommendation that the head assembly be left open until it dries out after the recommended daily rinsing in hot water. This makes the head assembly quite vulnerable to getting damaged (bumped) because it sticks out well beyond the shaver itself when it's open. The head protector can be mounted on the open head assembly but that's a bit tricky to do. If you don't put the protector on, the individual comb assemblies can be easily bumped and damaged. One other concern is that the 8240 seems to be more unstable when lying on its back than the older Norelco shavers. This means it will more easily roll to one side or the other than the older shavers if it is not carefully placed on a hard flat surface or if it is bumped while lying there. This may be a concern if it is placed too close to the edge of a solid surface (countertop, shelf, etc.) as it might easily roll to the side and fall off the surface. I can see this happening if a person is in a hurry and/or is not very careful when laying the shaver on a hard flat surface. Initial shave experience with the 8240XL - 5/22/2010: I have a relatively light beard and have been using Norelco shavers for over 35 years (perhaps longer). I had no problem with 1st shave irritation since my face is well accustomed to the Norelco system. I liked the feel of the 8240, the increased head / comb surface feels nice (3 cutting rings per comb instead of the previous single cutting ring). Because of the increased cutting area I think my shaves go slightly more quickly than with my previous 6615 shaver - but that is not a certainty. I can not feel anything at all while shaving and my 8240 shaver seems much quieter and smoother than my previous 6615 shaver. Maybe that'll change as it gets older and the newness (a.k.a. sharpness) wears off. This is what all of my previous Norelco shavers have done. Since I've only had the 8240XL about a month at this writing it's probably too soon to tell.
  73. I have been using the Norelco 8240XL a few weeks. I have bought a new Norelco shaver every few years for the past 25 years. The 8240XL replaced a Spectra 8891XL (a higher-end model when purchased). The 8240XL provides a better shave. It is the quickest and closest shave I can remember a Norelco giving me. I am still using the initial charge and unsure how many more shaves it will give me. This is the one issue I have with this model. Norelco should include some type of charge status indicator with all cordless models.
  74. This is a great shaver. I was worried that it wouldn't be as good as the 10 year old Norelce that I retired - but it is.
  75. I tried this out but it didn't cut neck/chin hair well, gave me A LOT of irritation/razor burn and even a few ingrown hairs. Also kind of a weird feeling, can pinch sometimes while shaving. The 3 head design just doesn't make sense, it can't effectively reach and cover places on the human face. I think the foil method is much better, especially for sensitive skin, although it's not a great alternative either. Rubbing your hair in circles isn't good either because then your hairs grow in all different directions which isn't good. I returned mine with no problems. Might work for some with very light facial hair.
  76. Have had Norelco for 6 weeks. Smooth...quiet...and reasonable close but not as close as the Panasonic was. Horrible base. Very dangerous..With razor in it easily tips..falls into sink, so be carefull and NEVER lets it stand plugged in near a sinkfull of water.
  77. You will get a better shave trying to take the dollar bills and run them across your face than you will get from this shaver. Not only does it not give a close shave, but I seem to keep bumping the razor head release button as well - each time, the thing flies apart with three razor heads, their respective covers, and the 3-pronged bracket that is supposed to hold them together racing for the sink drain. More than once, I've had to take the trap off the sink and fish these out.
  78. I am making the switch from a traditional blade and shave-gel to electric shaving system with the Philips Norelco 8240XL. Based on my experience a few years ago which left me with irritated skin and ingrown hairs, I was not expecting much. After a few weeks of use, I am pleasantly surprised. No skin irritation or any more ingrown hairs than I get with traditional shaving.<br /><br />Pluses: It is easy to use and much faster than traditional shaving. After using it, it is very easy to clean using the included brush. The kit includes a small charger (no bulky transformer which makes transportation easier) and a collapsible case. I appreciate the case versus the hard case I had with the shaver I used a few years ago; the form factor for storage is convenient and thoughtful.<br /><br />Minuses:<br />1. It leaves a mess. Every time I shave the counter is scattered with little hairs. Rather than gathering them up in a lather like traditional shaving or keeping them inside (which would require more frequent cleanings), the 8240XL seems to just spit the little hairs all over a 3 foot diameter. It, therefore, requires a little more cleanup than traditional shaving and is not as good for shaving in the car as I might have hoped.<br />2. Not good for long hairs. It is very effective at clipping off day-old hairs. As hairs get longer it tends to miss them. This is a self-perpetuating problem. If I shave quickly and leave a few stragglers, there is a lesser chance that these will be clipped off tomorrow than the shorter ones. After a few days I have a few long hairs among a well-shaven face. At that point, I give it a run with the traditional razor which takes care of it. Likewise, if I skip shaving for a few days between workdays, it is pretty much useless, very slow, and somewhat more irritating to my skin than traditional shaving. That said, if I'm careful to do a thorough job each morning without skipping days, the 8240XL is very effective and quite a bit more time-efficient than my old method.<br /><br />Understanding its limitations and maximizing its benefits, I am happy to make daily use of the Norelco 8240XL supplementing it with traditional shaving at times. Especially considering the low price point, I would recommend the 8240XL with some cautions to those considering it.Understanding its limitations and maximizing its benefits, I am happy to make daily use of the Norelco 8240XL supplementing it with traditional shaving at times. Especially considering the low price point, I would recommend the 8240XL with some cautions to those considering it.
  79. This my 4th Norelco shaver is indeed the best ever :corded/cordless-swivel head for navigating the jawline-long lasting battery shavetime with 1 hour recharge(for me that's the best of the best)-easy to clean under hot water.Of course the most important feature of a good razor is a clean close shave and this razor delivers.Some folks might want to step up to the next 82 model which alerts you to a low battery charge but that's a personal choice.

Cons: ----- You must move head SLOWLY to get the best cut. Case won't hold recharge cord like on older models. Not sure pivoting head will last.

  84. Used WAHL trimmer for my left cheek to trim my week-old \\"beard\\", which I grew to test this product. Then used Philips-Norelco trimmer to trim hair on my right cheek. Neither of those do a good job, but they do it somehow. Then used Philips-Norelco 8240XL shaver (cost $95) to shave. Took longer than usually with a shaver - entire 10-15 minutes instead of 2-3 minutes. When I thought I was done I found long hair on my upper neck which I went through many times with the shaver. The shaver pulls hair even after trimmer job and has a weak motor that does not have enough strong rotation for a fast, close, painless shave. Shaver leaves face red and with whiskers sticking out and a lot to desire. To compare with a $68 Remington 7130 - I'd rather keep Remington, even if Remington is built sloppy and cheap and it's head falls apart (etc.), but at least the Remington does a fast and painless job. Also - I own a 14 year old and top of the line very expensive PHILIPS Philishave, which needs a new head, but the Philips factory in Europe (and USA) refuses to supply me with a new head for it... That's the PRICE we pay for \\"patriotic\\" American corporations sending jobs overseas and bringing inferior products in exchange. No more PHILIPS - NORELCO for me! I will be looking for a \\"Made in Japan\\" Japanese brand shaver. Or at least \\"Made in USA\\" one. (8240XL) not recommended.
  85. Having read all of the positive reviews, I wonder to myself if we're talking about the same product. I admit to being a blade user but all the \\"close as a blade\\" advertising made me decide to give it a try.<br /><br />After getting the nearly impossible packaging open the first thing that sours me is the lack of some kind of rechargeable base or stand I can put the razor into when I'm done. It doesn't seem like too much to ask for considering this is a $100 product and leaving the razor and a power cord lying around is a hassle.<br /><br />The Norelco looks and feels nice in my hand with a nice big on/off switch and it's noticably quieter than the Norelco I owned years ago. The one difference I see now is the entire base rotates up and down as opposed to just the blades in my old shaver. But looks aren't as important as performance in my opinion so let's talk about the shave.<br /><br />First let me say my skin probably hasn't been toughened up by constant shaving. Being self employed, my face has lived the life of luxury as shaving is mostly optional and, when done, it's with an electric trimmer for a 5 o'clock shadow. A blade is used only when necessary. I flip on the Norelco, go to work on my shadow and... YEEEOOWWW!!! Ripping and tearing through my face like a hatchet through the jungle. It's a bloody mess. More pain when I put on the aftershave. I get irritation using a blade but this is so bad the irritation doesn't stop even after the aftershave stop burning. They said it'd take a while (as long as a month) for your skin to 'adjust' but they didn't say you wouldn't be able to show your face in public. What was shaving with a Norelco like? Like falling off a motorcycle at 50mph and hitting the pavement, face first.<br /><br />Giving them the benefit of the doubt, I stuck it out for a full month. Future sessions weren't as bloody but they sure did hurt and irritation continues to linger even after applying aftershave. The frequent yank of hairs being ripped out is not the most pleasant feeling in the world. Worst of all the resulting shave is certainly not as close as a blade. I might look shaved but I still feel the bristles. It's a laborious process as well, rubbing over the same hairs over and over as a lot gets missed. Shaving with an electric takes longer than a blade even with the added time spent applying shaving cream and rinsing off.<br /><br />I gave it the college try but after a month I'm sticking with a blade, thanks. Gillette's Mach II and Mach III razors and some quality shaving cream have done me fine. I'm not saving any time using an electric and I'm in a lot less pain using a blade.st pleasant feeling in the world. Worst of all the resulting shave is certainly not as close as a blade. I gave it the college try but after a month I'm sticking with a blade, thanks. Gillette's Mach II and Mach III razors and some quality shaving cream have done me fine. I'm not saving any time using an electric and I'm in a lot less pain using a blade.

  103. Did a bit of research on Norelco shavers before replacing my husband's 7000 series model. This is a step up! It's a better engineered product, with more advanced cutting heads and a better look on top of that. I noticed right away he didn't have 5 o'clock shadow when he came home. He commented that it got hairs on his neck he used to have to touch up with a blade. For about twice the price, you get: *longer battery life/ very short charge time *extra pivot point- the whole cutting head can flex, in addition to the 3 individual cutting heads *more shaving area--what does 50% more cutting surface really mean? the product is not bigger, there is just less wasted space. a noticeable improvement over 7000s. *good travel case (fits shaver only) to prevent scratching. Don't spend any more than this! You will get an improved product without paying for any extra flashy features. Get rid of the old HQ8 blades and move on to the HQ9.

  109. I have been using this product for several weeks now and rate this product as OK.   117. I have been using norelco shavers for many years and when the battery of my previous shaver started acting up (could barely hold enough charge for 15mins of shaving), I decided to buy another norelco. I wanted a shaver that could be cleaned by directly rinsing the head and that was cordless. I settled on the 8240XL as it seemed a good price-performance trade-off. I'm not utterly disappointed but the 8240XL is certainly not a significant improvement over my older norelco that used the HQ5 heads. Specifically, while it shaves slightly faster (rotation speed of the heads is higher, which \\"fixes\\" a long-standing issue with norelco shavers compared to other brands), the HQ9 heads don't really provide a closer shave than the HQ5 heads. As a matter of fact, they do a substantially worse job on the upper lip (I have a hard beard) where after over a month of usage (so it's not a question of getting your beard used to it), I have so far not been able to get as close a shave as I used to with the HQ5 heads. I guess that the \\"fancier\\" layout of holes and slits on the HQ9 is just that, fancier and not better. Except for this, the shaver is fine. It does clean easily simply by putting the head under running water. It recharges reasonably fast, and it appears that one charge does indeed hold 50 mins of shaving time. The one other shortcoming of notice is that there is no \\"low charge\\" indicator (my old shaver had a display showing the number of shaving minutes left in the battery, which was convenient), which makes knowing when you are about to run out of battery a bit challenging, especially since norelco recommends recharging the shaver only when the battery is nearly depleted. The next model up does have a low battery indicator, and I would recommend spending the few additional dollars for that model, simply because of the added convenience.
  118. I have had an earlier version of cordless Norelco shaver. The new Philips Norelco SpeedXL shaver is a great replacement. The pop-up trimmer is perfect for grooming and the three floating heads give one a very close and clean cut. I especially like the pop-up heads that allow for rapid cleaning-out of whisker stubble. The shape of the razor is very comfortable.
  119. My previous Norelco razor (6863XL)was purchased around 8 years ago. It was a great razor that worked well even with the original blades(!). It started to make noise so after looking at options and reviews I went with the 8240XL. I was nervous because of the poor reviews some Norelco razors received from loyal customers. I have been using Norelco for about 30 years. I have used the 8240XL three times so far and have been disappointed each time. True, it is quieter and the head pivots nicely. The bottom line is that it shaves no better (perhaps worse) than my 8 year old razor with the original blades. As others have noted, the battery level indicator is a step backwards from previous models. It takes many passes to get a decent shave. I even recharged it overnight to make sure the battery was full. Since I have used it, it appears I cannot return it to Amazon. I plan to return it directly to Philips after I use it for 3 weeks as part of their 45 day guarantee. I'll be looking at Braun and Panasonic.

  122. I bought this at Costco on impulse, looked like a good upgrade and a good deal with the extra head. My last shaver was a discount deal, similar style but was so wimpy it took a noticeably long time and multiple passes, leaving lots of single hairs, and the motor was so weak it pulled painfully every few seconds. I wrote it off to the cheap price, you get what you pay for. What a surprise - this unit has all the same problems! This thing is the most anemic, wimpy shaver I've ever used. The motor seems overloaded with a full charge and as a result pulls painfully every few seconds like the old cheap (corded)one, leaves lots of hairs behind uncut. How much more could it cost to include a real motor and/or battery? An extra dollar? These guys know by now how design a razor; chalk up one for the marketeers. Junk in a nice package.
  123. I have purchased Norelco's in this price range fo a very long time. They have, and this one does a great job. The good news is that you can open this one and wash it out in the sink. Therefore it is easy to clean and you don't have to worry about dumping the stubble. I would definitely buy it again.
  124. Used this shave for 5 months now, and I have to say I'm not happy with it. It completely ignores tons of hair on the neck, and only scrubbing it with a side cutter (or whatever it's called) will more of less cut the hair about half-way. Mustaches area, if you let the hair grow there for a couple of days, will be a pain to shave. And I mean \\"pain\\". From the very start, when blades on it were completely new, it would pinch and tear out the hair from the skin, which is quite painful.   128. I, like many blossoming professionals had grown up with the Philips brand and its glowing reliability. Now, the only thing radiating is the wave of screaming hair follicles from this face-grinder. Looking for something that had evolved at the same (and hopefully more balanced) rate as myself, the Philips razor has grown to be become a beautiful looking machine, while degrading to a set of primitive spinning blades on a gimmicky foundation. I have effectively paid 50% more for the razor than my last one, and in return have a 10% drop in shaving experience, with its inferior trimmer, weak motor and deadly neck trimming performance. I constantly return to follicles missed, and have doubled my shaving time. I no longer wonder why Philips has become ever-so-focused on its aesthetic appeal, as their actual performance has reached a mediocre plateau. Looking to move up to the next best thing in shaving technology? Go all-or-nothing with a premium foil shaver, or save some cash with the reliable cream and blade.

He has had a problem with his chin breaking out where his football helmet chin strap touches his face and his coaches suggested he try an electric shaver). Despite the fact that he only has to shave about ever third or fourth day, the whining emails and text messages became too much.<br /><br />Anyway, I wanted a razor that did not cost an arm and a leg but at the same time did not want a hunk of junk. Things have a way of disappearing in the black hole he calls his dorm room so I did not want to spend a fortune on something that disappeared into the same void as the many other odds and ends have.<br /><br />I also wanted something that was simple, simple, simple as my grandson takes after me and is not what you would call mechanically inclined, i.e. he has trouble changing a tire and installing flashlight batteries.<br /><br />Yes, I wanted something inexpensive, workable, easy to use and very easy to maintain.<br /><br />For his use this razor is absolutely perfect. He has been delighted with it. The complaining has ceased, he looks quite well groomed and so far has not lost it.<br /><br />I could not want for more.<br /><br />Don Blankenship<br />The Ozarks
  132. This was my first electric razor. I had previously been shaving with manual Gilette Fusion razors, so that is my only basis of comparison. I was looking for something that didn't irritate my skin as much as a manual, but as far as closeness of shave, there is no comparison. The manual razor will give you a much closer shave, but generally the tradeoff will be a bit more redness & irritation, especially if you shave with a manual everyday. I have been using it for about 3 months now with no major complaints. It is pretty quiet in action, has a long battery life, and does a pretty good job as an everyday shaver. It does have difficulty shaving the neck and mustache areas, as I have to go over those areas multiple times to cut the hairs down to a reasonable level. The sideburn trimmer feature is OK, not great. But overall, I would say far less irriation than the manual razor.
  133. I did my research and purchased this razor for my husband. He couldn't be more pleased with the close shave and the ease of cleaning. Also, it seems to hold it's charge well.
  134. I have to take the cleaning head apart to clean so I can get a shave about twice a week. Then I have to keep the cutters separate, and reassemble the head. I am very displeased with this shaver, and would like your comments as to how to resolve this problem. Edward Schlaich Lexington, Ma 02421 781-862-1529
  135. THIS RAZOR IS ALL THAT THEY SAY ABOUT. I HAVE BEEN USING THIS BRAND FOR OVER 59 YR.S GREAT PRICE TOO!!!! I LOVE IT.
  136. I just received my Razor the other day. As with other reviews getting the razor out of the package is a little bit of a chore. I did as instructed and let the razor charge overnight even though after an hour, the indicator light was blinking fully charged. The razor is much quieter than my old norelco razor. The head pivots which alows for a more closer shave. The shave itself was smooth and thus far, no irratation to speak of. Clean-up was easy as you jut pop up the head and rinse with hot water. There are no bells and whistles (carry case is flimsy and there is no charging stand) and it is as others have stated a basic razor. But it is such an upgrade from my old norelco in which the batteries were wearing down and the shave was very rough. So far I am pleased with the shave and at $79.99 on amazon (including shipping) it is very good value for the price. Thus, if you are looking for a good basic electric razor, this one is a pretty good choice.
  137. Ordered the norelco speed 8240 for my husband. He absolutely loves it. It is easy to use, quick charging and has several different types of cutting blades.
  138. I have used Norelco shavers for about 20 years. I am very happy with the 8240. I think it gives a slightly closer shave than my previous shaver. It is very quiet and comfortable to hold. The shave is very comfortable. It is easy to clean (I do once a week). Gives more than 2 weeks per charge. Only problem is that it suddenly stops when the charge is gone without any warning. However, I understand that it works on cord.
  139. Haven't used a electric razor in years and wasn't sure if I'd like it. To my delight its been the best shave I've had in years. Wish I would have purchased it years ago. The tender skin under the neck is not affected at all. Would recommend this to anyone looking for a close shave. Ron D. Bells, TX
  140. Well I like using an electric. this one worked great the first few times. Now a month later I find myself having to go over the same spot a few times to get a smooth shave. Oh well.
  141. I bought this shaver after using a Norelco 7775X for years with great success. The 8240XL, however, is a literally painful disappointment. It snags and yanks hairs on the sensitive areas of my neck. Feels like you're getting jabbed by a needle and will quickly jerk you out of a sleepy early-morning haze. Maybe it's got something to do with the way they redesigned the combs with all the added little holes instead of full, open combs all the way around each cutter. It also takes more time spent shaving - i.e. multiple passes - to get a close shave. This shaver is truly not worth what I paid for it. I will be sending it back to Philips Norelco per their 45-day guarantee and purchasing a different brand.
  142. I have had norelco shavers for at least the last 20 years. The models with cord/cordless capability are probably best. Newer models do give a cleaner/closer shave with less skin irritation.<br />A good solid purchase at a reasonable price that will last until battery burnout and then time for a newer model.
  143. My original review for this razor was not good, however, now that my skin has gotten used to it, I felt obligated to write another review. The 8240XL comes with a very nice travel pouch and features a pop-up trimmer. At first, it took my skin some time to adjust to this razor because I was used to using the Cool Skin model (wet shave). Eventually, I decided to try the Lectric pre-shave lotion and since then, this razor has been excellent. I have very sensitve skin, so I need to use the lotion. For only $5 or $6 you can get a bottle with lots of lotion and it will last a long time. For anyone with sensitive skin, that is what I recommend. This razor now gives me a smooth shave and I am very pleased!
  144. I have used Norelco shavers for many years and when my last one stopped working I looked again on line for another one primarily for travel. (I have 2) This one works well as I expected, but there are a couple of improvements that you might consider. 1) You advertise a larger area of the shaving head to cut more at a time. I found that the area around the blades is too wide that it hinders my shaving next to my nose. 2) This one worked for a long time after my first charge, but it has no blinking red light to let me know when my next charge is necessary. It just died. This is hardly something I want to happen on my next camping trip where there is no electricity to plug into. I'll have to remember to charge before any trip I take. Otherwise it is a great, comfortable shave. Tom
  145. I bought this for my husband when his last electric razor died. We both like the results of this one and he reports that it is smooth and easy.
  146. I have been using this razor for 4 months, and it took a while to learn how to better use it for my skin. I have a very sensitive skin, when I shave wet I can only shave downwards, otherwise my skin gets very irritated. I bought this shaver because, as I have to shave everyday for professional reasons, doing it wet was not good either. The electrical razor is less aggressive to the skin. After a month adapting to it and finding out how to shave, I found out that, even though it's an electrical shaver, I must also shave only downwards or from the left to the right and vice-versa, not upwards. It's not as close as wet shaving, but it fits my needs well because I can shave everyday and get a decent look without getting my skin irritated. For those in my situation, a very practical choice! PS: As everybody here knows (and Norelco should also), the lack of battery life indicator is a downside...
  147. works a lot better than the cheaper norelco and holds charge for awhile no indicator when charge is getting low.
  148. [[ASIN:B001AMRQ2W Philips Norelco Speed 8240 Men's Shaving System]] Previously I was using a Norelco Razor 5885XL for 8 years and things started to fail, so I replaced it with a Philips Norelco Speed 8240. I have been using it for a month and it is a pleasure to use. I have not had to recharge it yet after 25 days of use. It gives me a close shave but not so close that it leaves your face burning. It is very easy to clean, pop the heads open and run under running water for 30 seconds or so, then set it up and let it dry. The razor has a nice feel when you pick it up, light, but fits the hand perfectly. It is quiet and gives the impression that the motor is weak but when it hits the heavy places in my beard, it doesn't slow and leaves my face nice and smooth. The razor has a tilt head that dramatically helps getting a close shave when compared to my old razor. This is in addition to three rotary heads that move independently to contour to your face. I think it is a great buy.
  149. I bought the 8240XL for my Dad for Fathers Day and he loves it!!! It gives him a close comfortable shave. I own the 8260XL and the reason I did not get him that model is because I knew he would not use the Jet Clean System. This razor is very good for my Dad, but as for me it's a different story! I collect Norelco Electric Razors. I have the Spectra James Bond Razor, the Smart Touch XL with the minute display, and the Arcitec 1050cc with the Jet Clean System, and the 8260XL with the Jet Clean System. Now which one shaves the best? First, unlike my Dad, I have a heavy dark beard and I have to shave every morning and sometimes in the afternoon to keep from getting a shadow. For me, all of these razors shave ok, just ok, never as close as a blade!, but the best of these razors are the Spectra James Bond Razor and the Smart Touch XL. These two razors shave pretty close. The 8200 series is ok, and I will leave it at that. The razors in the 8200 series are all pretty much the same except as you move up the line you get more bells and whistles. All the razors in the 8200 series shave the same. I shave with the Arcitec 1050cc and the 8260XL and rotate between the two. At present, they are doing a pretty good job, but sometimes I bring my other razors out of retirement. I like to use Mennen Afta Pre Electric Loation and a little talc powder which helps me to achieve a close comfortable shave. Williams Lectric Shave is too greasey. After shaving, I put on a little Mennen Afta After Shave Skin Conditioner or Nivea Post Shave Balm which helps my skin from becoming dry. I do not get razor burn from any of these electric razors. I do like the Jet Clean System that came with my Arcitec 1050cc and 8260XL. I always wash out my razors before I use them in the cleaning system which helps to save on the cleaning solution. The cleaning solution last about a month and it can be purchased at Walmart or you can have it delivered right to your door every month by purchasing it from Amazon. Norelco has been a trad in my family for years. My Dad, Grandfathers and Great Grandfathers all shaved with Norelco Electric Razors. I'm 47 and I have been shaving with them for the most part since I started shaving. I have had problems with Norelco though. There have been times when a relatively new Norelco Razor would just quit on me, but I am happy to say that Philips Norelco ALWAYS replaced the defective razor! If you want to get a close comfortable shave stick with Norelco. Shaving with Norelco Electric Razors is better then the mess of soap and water and you don't have to buy blades and shaving cream all the time.-Michaelit from Amazon. Norelco has been a trad in my family for years. My Dad, Grandfathers and Great Grandfathers all shaved with Norelco Electric Razors. I'm 47 and I have been shaving with them for the most part since I started shaving. I have had problems with Norelco though. There have been times when a relatively new Norelco Razor would just quit on me, but I am happy to say that Philips Norelco ALWAYS replaced the defective razor! Shaving with Norelco Electric Razors is better then the mess of soap and water and you don't have to buy blades and shaving cream all the time.-Michael
  150. This particular Speed replaced a base-model, roughly 4-year old Quadra.....now relegated to occasional use on my son's 15YO chin.....and I'm neither terribly excited nor disappointed with it. The 8240XL is not as physically sturdy as its predecessor.....which really is no surprise as older designs are \\"updated\\"......and I'm still getting used to its feel in my hand (more angular, and marginally smaller, than the old Quadra). I also note no evidence the Speed head design has contributed much of anything to the shaving action versus its older counterparts. But, at the end of the day, it does the job for which it's intended; and that's really all I can ask. I also picked it up at an EXCELLENT price. Amazon's price at the time was <$80.....the price is now in the low 90's, much closer to the typical retail price.....PLUS another 15% off with an E-coupon. With free shipping, I paid under $70; a SERIOUS bargain for a current model (and about the same as I paid for the old Quadra on Walmart clearance 4-years ago). Had I paid $90+ for the unit, there's decent chance I'd have de-rated it by one star. One more point; it's my opinion that the Norelco rotary design is more effective on comparatively soft (or perhaps somewhat curly) whiskers. If one's whiskers are extremely stiff, I believe a foil-style (like a Braun) might be a better match. As an exclusive Braun user for 20 years.....and exclusively Sunbeams before that.....I took a flyer on the aforementioned Quadra to see how Norelco would work. It gave me a better shave with 3 year old blades than a Sunbeam or Braun EVER gave me right out of the box.
  151. I decided to make a switch from traditional razors to the Norelco electric. I read a lot of reviews, did a lot of research, and decided to go mid-level price and features with this model. The instructions say to give the electric at least 21 days for your skin to get used to the change. I did, and I am back to shaving with a traditional razor. Not only did the electric leave my face still feeling rough, it was more work and much more time consuming based on the fact that I had to go over some areas over and over and over again to get missed stubble or single whiskers. In addition, the small hairs make a mess of the bathroom counter. The motor seems cheap and doesn't have much power. I am returning the product and will be returning back to shaving in the shower with my trusty old razor. For those of you who have always shaved using a razor and now have decided to try electric, I wouldn't go to the trouble. You'll never get as smooth or as nice of a shave...and the electric takes twice as long.
  152. Horrible quality control. Received it as a gift for Xmas 2008. Replaced first one in March. Second one in June. So 3 units in 6 months. It's September now and I have the same problems as the last 2. Luckily it's fairly easy to get a new one under warranty, just call them up and they ship you a new one. It appears as though the motors keep burning out. I charge exactly like the manual states (12 hours first charge) and use the unit until there is no power left. Then I recharge for an hour till the light starts blinking. The last two units have had ZERO water run in them as I thought that was the problem with the first one (even though the manual states that is how you clean the unit). I use the unit 3-4x a week so we're talking AT MOST under 50 shaves per razor and then it croaks. Horrible product, avoid. Had my last Norelco razor for half a decade and it still works, guess I'll just buy a new head for it.
  153. I wish I had bought a better Quality shaver this my 3rd shaver from this Mfg. the others shaved better and gave a closer shave.
  154. I am absolutely thrilled with the quality and amazingly quiet effective performance of this shaver. It has been 20 years since I last bought a Philips, and although I liked my old model, the advances in technology by Philips have been incredible. This shaver gives me a close comfortable shave which I thought was only possible with a wet shave - and without the nicks, cuts, and time-consuming application of foam soaps. No more putting off shaving - I enjoy it now! I like the quiet operation, and the impressive duration that the battery stays charged. I also like how hair stays inside the shaver, and being able to flip the top, and wash the heads out after a shave. The pivoting heads are an advancement, allowing much better contact with the skin's contours. The shaver comes with a soft little carry bag with a cleaning brush, and a manual. It needs a 12 hour charge before using the first time, even though the charging light may blink after an hour. Well done, Philips! It's nice to know that there are still such high quality products out there!
  155. An excellent shave for the money!
  156. I've only used this a few times, but it is so much better than what I was shaving with before. I used to shave with disposable, plastic 2 or 3 blade shavers, and they give you a good close shave, but you have to put on the shaving cream, etc. and it is kind of a pain (and can take awhile). I also had a Panasonic ES4025 electric razor that I occasionally used, but was hard to use and didn't give a good shave. This new Philips Norelco 8240xl is light years ahead of the Panasonic. You will get a really good shave. And importantly, it is very quick. I probably can finish shaving 2 or 3 times faster than before, and it is much less cumbersome --- think of the time you'll save over the life of the razor! Maybe if you spend more you can get an even better shaving experience, I don't know, but for me this is currently a great shaving solution. Highly recommended.
  157. I bought this to replace a Norelco 66??XL that had done me well for about the last six years or so. My old one still gave an ok shave but the battery was becoming very unreliable. The first two things that hit me with the 8240XL was the lightness of the shaver and how quiet it is. Matter of fact, it is so quiet that I first thought it didn't have the power to do a good job. A month in and the low noise level still impresses me each day. The shave is also improved over the older model. The heads seem to have more pivot and so hug the curves better. Closeness is improved a little but I typically replaced the heads on my older model pretty regularly to maintain a pretty close shave all the time. You'll always (unless you're one of those guys who just can't get a decent shave with an electric) notice a closer shave with new heads so I guess it is just a matter of how long they provide that closeness. I wouldn't say that this model cut my shaving time or requires significantly less passes but I am pleased with the performance. I've used Norelco electrics for many years and they've always worked well for a long time.<br /><br />Update (11/12/12): Nearly three years and this Norelco is still going strong. Of course I have had to replace the blades once or twice but the battery life is as good as when I bought it which is about a couple of weeks.

  163. Not very happy with this shaver. I own two older Norelco's (5800 series) and they seem to run at faster speed and shave better than the new 8240. Also, the unit comes with an external (charger) power supply which is a nuisance, instead of just a cord. With the older shavers, you could pack your cord and shaver into the pouch they give you which is great for traveling, but with this 8240 model, you can't do that so you have to remember to pack both the shaver and separate power supply. The fact that I can rinse the shaver under the faucet is no big benefit and did not affect my decision to purchase this model. This is probably my last Norelco shaver purchase unless they eliminate the external power supply and use a faster shaver motor. I don't care what it costs - I just want a good shave every morning with my electric razor.

  167. Prior to purchasing the Philips Norelco 8240XL, I considered the 8260 model that included the cleaning stand and battery charge remaining indicator, but didn't think it was worth $60 more. The product arrived in that impossible-to-open-without-impaling-yourself plastic packaging, but I managed to get the contents out without losing a digit. The shaver feels sturdy and well made, easy to clean and maintain, and is probably one of the better electric shavers on the market. The problem is the length of hair it leaves behind. Immediately after using the shaver my facial hair was long enough to grab and pull out with my index finger and thumb. I estimate it is the equivalent length of 16 hours after shaving with my manual razor. Granted, I have not found any electric shaver that is satisfactory, and I gave the product 2 stars because I am certain it is good as far as electric shavers go. I desire a stubble-free smooth close shave which in my experience this product cannot provide, so I'm returning it for a refund and will stick to my Gillette manual razor.

  169. Bought this to replace my old Norelco 8000 series shaver whose battery died on me completely a year ago. I have lost a lot of hair since I had my original electric razor so I bought this to not only shave my beard but also my entire head. Needless to say, it did not disappoint. Pros: * good close shave (after a short week of adjustment); * quiet motor; * battery lasts long (just under a week) between charge cycles; * quick charging (1.5 hrs for a full charge); * no mess/collects cut hair in small reservoir; * reservoir easy to clean; Cons: * not very portable (size wise) though much lighter than my old unit; * wish case had a small pocket for the cleaning brush; Bottom line, I'll definitely recommend this shaver (Philips Norelco 8240) to anyone who's looking for a good hassle-free shave.
  170. Just for context, I am a picky shaver (one who shaves) with sensitive skin and a round, slightly chubby face. I also shave against the grain for a very close shave. I used to shave with a razor, but got tired of cutting myself. :-) I first got a Panasonic ES8077S. It worked well, but pinched me too much and gave me cuts (I now know this was because I was using it wet). Shave was about 90% as close as using a razor in the shower. I switched to a Remington MS680CS for the past year and it was fine. Noisy, but OK. Cheaper than the others. Shave (dry) was about 70% as close as using a razor. Then I got tired of the level of stubble I had at night and decided to try something new. So I got a Norelco Speed 8240. It was VERY quiet, but the shave was worse. Shave (dry) was about 55% as close as using a razor. I've tried going in circles, going slow, going fast, pushing hard, pushing slightly, etc. It's just not as close. I have a round, slightly chubby face, but I'd heard that Norelcos are BETTER than foil shavers with my kind of face. I've gone back to Panasonic.
  171. I bought this electric shaver to replace an older model I had bought from Singapore, which I had for about 3 years.<br /><br />This shaver has good charging time, about an hour, and runs for a month if used twice a week. Also, its not noisy at all and it's cleaning mechanism is also very easy and quick.<br /><br />However, it's razors are not sharp enough to shave off my hair in one sweep, it takes about 2 to 3 swipes for me to clean off hair, but even then a few tiny hair remain on the sides. It is only good for shaving off hair around corners, like your chin. Other than that, I only use it for general cleaning and sometimes still use my older model since that one cleans off all hair in one sweep, although it creates lot of noise.
  172. This is my third Norelco rechargeable, and I end up using them until the battery doesn't take a charge and moving on figuring other components could use replacement as well. I will admit that my last Norelco seemed to be in good enough shape where replacing the battery would be worthwhile so I ordered one and attempted to replace it myself...no go. Turns out you have to be very good with a soldering gun and even them it's tricky. Ended up trashing the circuit board and wasted $5 on a battery. Anyway, as far as the 8240, I've had it about six months and use it daily. It doesn't have quite the heft of my previous Norelcos but seems like it will hold together. The ability to wash the shaver down with water is a plus but it does leave a coating of \\"shmutz\\" inside the workings that you'll deal with when you finally break the shaver down to clean the heads and the assembly pieces (which they recommend monthly). Norelco offers so many different models your head will spin when you try to choose. I got this one because it was in stock and I needed it right away. The 8240 has a pivoting head that looks kind of cool but it adds mechanical complexity and I'm not sure it really makes the shave better. My previous ones had fixed heads and that seemed fine as far as following facial contours. One thing this model doesn't have is an indicator for when the battery needs to be recharged, and I notice now that some of their cheaper models do have that feature---and it's good to have. The 8340 runs and runs, never slowing down RPMs like my old shaver then all of a sudden it just stops dead and you have to charge it-- no warning, no extra time. I suspect this has to do with a different battery type, maybe Li? A good feature probably common to other Norelcos is the quick charging time, and you can shave with it as it's charging even if it was dead when you plugged it in. Overall it's a good shaver, I worry a little about durability due to light weight and more plastic components, it's lacking a low battery indicator, and the cost is a little high with competing Norelco models at lower price points with some good features.

  177. Because of some surgery affecting my face, I had to quit using a wet blade system. The Norelco brand seemed best becasue of the floating heads that conform better to the hills and valleys of my new facial features. I've been using it for about 8 months and, after an inital adjustment period, am quite pleased. The charge lasts about 2 weeks. The shave is not as close as a blade, but is certainly acceptable. I use Williams pre-share, which also helps. I gave it a 4 rather than 5 stars because it's not as good trimming the beard at the bottom of my side burns. The built in trimmer only is good for cutting back the hairs on the side burns. I like being able to rinse clean. The directions recommend overhauling the shaver head about once a month by dismantling and rinsing in alcohol, so there is a maintenace issue. Recommend for good value electric razor.
