  180. I have pretty sensitive skin and its easy for my skin to get irritated with a close shave. This shaver is fantastic at giving me a close shave without the irritation i get from other shavers. Its also incredibly quiet, pretty well built, and the battery lasts a very long time. I've had it for a month and a half. Since i primarily work from home i don't have to shave each day. Usually every second or third day. In the last month and a half i've only had to recharge it once and that was yesterday. As i have to take trips overseas every couple months, and for a week or two at a time, its refreshing to have a shaver that will hold a charge in my checked bag and give me great shaves the entire trip. One last bonus is the power supply runs on 120-230v 50/60hz. So with a $2 plug adapter for whatever region i am in i can charge it anywhere in the world if i need to extend my stay. I'm giving it 4 stars instead of 5 because there's no battery life indicator on it. I still highly recommend this razor.
  181. does its job but slowly, probably due to a slow and weak motor. very quiet, gentle on my skin. the battery is good, lasts for many sessions. overall, good for not so close shave and probaly not good enough for guys with thick stubble.
  182. Initially, my husband loved his shaver, but it didn't hold up very long.
  183. i really don't know. i bought as a present. i don't know something about this item. i did't hear something from my friend.
  184. I think the multiple floating head concept is way over rated in that my first Norelco, many years ago, cut about the same as this one. I do not like the grip on this model as much as another model I presently have. The charge does hold for a long period, however, a warning that batteries were nearly expired would be ideal, rather than simply dying in the middle of a shave.
  185. The razor was to my surprise much better than expected. After about a week of my skin getting used to it (I used a Braun foil razor before) and me learning how to use it well I managed to achieve much closer cuts than the previous razor with less irritated skin in comparable time. Definitely a recommended buy if that's the price range You're looking at.
  186. I love this shaver. After juggling all types of shaving cream, all types of razors, frequently having to buy normal razor blades (I watched some idiot deluded into thinking he was a genius by cleaning his normal razor blades on his jeans, on youtube, when electric razor is so superior). Anyways, this saves time. It's simple. I shave more frequently (daily) because it's so simple and fast. I still can't believe for how many years I lathered up with shaving cream and spent 4-5 times as long on shaving. Granted, if I want an extremely close shave I may use a razor, but I'm fairly certain that I haven't used a normal razor since getting this 10 months ago. It's immensely resourceful. When I cut my own hair, the trimmer feature trims sideburns and back of hair so I (with my pocket-knife, and yes, this sounds absurdly rugged, but I have two mult-use devices that work great for differnet tasks, I can give myself a full haircut that looks amazing and awesome with trimmings iwth this). I use the trimmer to shape, thin out and trim moustache, too. The only reason why I've debated 4 or 5 stars is I wish the shave could be a bit closer. It's hard to shave where the neck meets jaw not because of design, just because of contour (my face / jaw / neck is slightly angular-gaunt making for a slightly sharper angle and thus more challenging shave, but still) this device rocks. It's smoothly replacd the absurdly antiquated hassle of old razorblades. I scoff at people who use those (and scoff at myself for using old razorblades for so long). 4.5/5 stars. (rounded up lol).
  187. I was satisfied with the Norelco shaver I had had for about five years except for the fact that recharging it had to be done weekly. The attraction of this model was the lithium ion battery which is advertized to last 17 days. I have now had the new razor for a month and still haven't had to recharge!
  188. I started using this shaver 25 days ago, and just ran out of charge today. Impressive. It's very quiet, fast, and gives great results (I'm still pretty smooth shaven 6 hours later). It can be cleaned quickly--just a rinse under hot running water. No problems and no complaints so far. This is my third Norelco shaver, and by far the best. Downsides are more annoying than important. Getting the package open is not a job for the faint-hearted. It takes a *strong* pair of scissors, a certain amount of sweat, and a modicum of strong language. And the included case is chintzy nylon with no padding and is too small to hold both the shaver and the charging cord. If you want to travel with it, this may not be a minor issue. Fortunately, I still have the case from my first Norelco, which has enough room for both.

Almost exactly at the 36 month mark, the shaves started missing hairs and taking much longer. Replacing the blades made the unit perform like new.<br /><br />(ie, I'm still thrilled with the product.)

I have a moderately heavy beard, so when Im shaving after a few days there is a little bit of pull, but not so much different than a straight blade. My previous razor was a Remington, which still works but would need new blades and battery. So I updated! The Norelco does shave closer than my Remington (age), and the rinse and air dry cleaning is so easy. If you're used to electic razors, then the transition to this razor is nothing. The packaging is so robust on this new model that you don't really know what you've got until you spend 15 minutes opening the carton. I will never buy another Norelco unless I can first hold it in my hand. In the meantime, I am headed to Batteries R Us to see if I can get a replacement for the battery in my old shaver.

  207. If your face and/or neck is easily irritated by shaving, you should try this model.<br /><br />I bought my first Philips 3 head shaver several years ago because it could be used in the shower and supposedly was gentle on the skin. Even with the best disposables, My neck always turned red after shaving and I routinely suffered bumps and cuts. I had to use after shave balm or my skin would sting for hours after shaving. I'd tried a previous foil type electric and that was painful, too.<br /><br />The first Philips 3 head model I got was the \\"Coolskin\\" model with the little Nivea shaving gel packet inserts. The gel was released through the shaver head with a push button. I found it to be much more gentle on my skin than disposables. The push button was handy, too. But, it took about 10 minutes to get a good shave (vs. 3 minutes with a disposable) because only the outer rings of the heads were shaving areas. Since it was an improvement, I kept it for a few years. Finding the Nivea packets became difficult, plus it was a drag to run out of shaving gel in the middle of a shave while standing in the shower. I ended up buying some non-foaming shave gel and that worked just fine.<br /><br />When the battery life dropped considerably on the Coolskin model, I bought the SpeedXL. I found it to be just as gentle on my skin, but since the whole head was a shaving area, it dramatically cut shaving time. When the heads became dull after a year, I replaced them. After 2 years, the battery life dwindled to the point where I had to charge it every day. That's when I looked to replace it. After shopping a lot online, I bought another 8240XL. When it came time to replace that unit, I shopped again and decided to try one of the fancy skinny Philips Norelco models for twice the price. I saw no benefit except that it was thinner and lighter, which wasn't worth the extra cost to me. I returned it and bought this one.<br /><br />Every few weeks, I use a good disposable on my face to get it really close. Overall, I am happy with this unit. It doesn't shave quite as closely as a good disposable and it takes a bit longer, but I can live with that. It's not worth the pain to get a faster, closer shave. It seems to be the best you can get for the money. I hear the upper end Brauns are better, but, I'm not willing to spend that kind of money.eally close. Overall, I am happy with this unit. It doesn't shave quite as closely as a good disposable and it takes a bit longer, but I can live with that. It's not worth the pain to get a faster, closer shave. It seems to be the best you can get for the money. I hear the upper end Brauns are better, but, I'm not willing to spend that kind of money.

They're prettier and sleeker, but they don't cut any better, or maybe even as good. I believe this is supposed to be Philips top of the line razor. I'm just going to say it isn't much better than the near bottom of the line Philips that I bought a few years ago.   217. This is a good shaver without bells and whistles. Unless i have done something incorrectly, i don't think there is a way to know when the charge is getting low. The shaver works at full speed and when the charge is gone, it just stops. There is no \\"slowing down\\" of the shaver. Notwithstanding, it shaves great. I would buy another.
  218. For many years, I was a higher end Braun or Panasonic shaver user, using it on my babyface and then blade shaving to finish while in the shower, which in honesty, gives you the closest possible nick-free shave without paying a barber to do it. About a year ago, I was given a 6340XL, which did a pretty good, if not fast, job, is reasonably quiet and pretty low irritation. For the money it turns out that it sells, a great deal, very decent shaver... which is still working fine and will be a \\"losable\\" travel shaver. The 8240 is a SUBSTANTIAL UPGRADE in the quality of the shave, and I noticed the difference in the very first shave... and the machine is obviously not yet broken in. It definitely cuts faster, though that can be attributed to sharper blades to a degree. My shaving is equivalent to 1/3 the amount most guys shave, so I'm easy on the shaver, but it can be tough on me. I expected to get some burn the first shave: nope. The new tilting head made for a much more comfortable shave and for much less tendency to want to press hard. Remember what your shop teacher told you: let the tool do the work! The cutter itself is the classic Norelco-designed Lift-and-Cut dual rotary system, with three heads. It works. The foils on this model have different shaped slots/openings, for different lengths/stiffnesses of hair, and it seems to work. The cutter head assembly simply flips up for cleaning, though it can be removed. Not sure this is actually an improvement, as I normally give the old metal head assembly of the 6340 a couple or three whacks upside down against the inside of the sink to knock out the stubble, tapping the body to loosen what's there. I'm not sure that I can get the same quick cleaning with this without fatiguing the flip-hinge, and don't think I can do the flat whack on the sink, either. Shame. This shaver, though, IS rated for HOT water cleaning, and they do specify HOT water, so don't burn your hand! Don't submerge the shaver, but it's okay if water runs out the bottom. Just don't plug it in to recharge until it's dry! This shaver is quieter and smoother sounding (less machine like, more motor like) than the 6000 series. That's a nice thing. Charge is similar in time and endurance. Based on the instructions, I think Philips is saving money using NiCd batteries instead of Lithium, but this is a midline shaver, so it's important to cycle the batteries properly. The first three or so charge cycles are the most important, and you'll likely get to the end of your warranty without problems if you do it right in the beginning... that's only about 50 charges, and NiCd batteries are usually good for 100-200 charge cycles, so you can probably count on this to make it through a couple of blade replacements. I like it. Amazon went nutty and put it on a crazy sale making it not much more (really) than buying a new blade/foil kit for my 6340, which I was actually here checking, when they sent the email with the sale price for a few more bucks! Glad I did it! Oh, it seems to require less frequent lubricating (according to the manual's schedule) so that would imply an improvement in precision for the parts, which would explain another review where the guy says it bests his 9000 series shaver from just a few years ago. IF you can live without the little plastic stand (I can) and without a Low Battery indicator (I can), this is a wonderful shaver in the under $100 price point, is better than my much more costly Braun and Panasonics (of a few years ago) were, and is quieter than the Braun by far. The Nor-Phil 6340 is still sold at Sears and such for a very fair price, and perhaps a little lower here on Amazon, but when you find THIS model 8240 on sale here, it's unbeatable for the money. And yes, the trimmer works well and is long enough and high enough to actually see what you're doing, a real problem with other brands. Highly recommended. Maybe not as good as a hot barber's straight edge shave, but whocan afford that every day???
  219. I've used Norelco electric razors for nearly four decades and until recently have always been very satisfied. The last electric razor that I purchased was in 2003. It had a numeric LCD display which told the amount of time left in the battery charge and the razor would continue to work at full strength for about 10-15 minutes past the time the display read zero. The razor lasted over eight years and continued to perform very well. By last year, the charge time had decreased significantly and the razor would not restart under the ten minute mark. I investigated replacing the battery and discovered that it was rather pricey to send it in. Replacing the battery by oneself involved a special driver to open the unit and soldering a black market battery in place. Since I was due for new razor blades, I opted to purchase a new razor. I investigated the models available and I found that Norelco had only a few models available with numeric LCD displays. They were only on the pricey pod-shaped SensoTouch models. I opted to purchase the 8240 XL since it was similar to my previous model and Amazon user ratings were fairly good. The 8240 XL looks like my last razor but it has more plastic and seems less durable. Instead of a coiled cord which previous models had, there is a thin, straight cord which always seems to tangle in my countertop drawer. There is no digital LCD and there is very little indication of when the battery is going to die. The razor does do a very good job with shaving except for the last ten minutes prior to the battery dying at which time the razor shaves slightly less efficiently.
  220. I have used Phillips Norelco shavers for over 30 years and have no major complaints with any of them. I just bought this product recently and it works as designed--quite flawlessly. Electric razors are not for everyone but I like to shave each and every day and the electric razor makes that chore pretty effortless. They really are not designed to cut through a really long and thick beard so this product may be a disappointment for those who like to give the face a rest over long weekends. I have tried a few other shaving systems but now has worked as well for me as the Phillips Norelco shavers--and this model is no exception. Having the ability to quickly rinse out the shaving head with tap water is a big plus. I try to stick with the mid-range product--such as this model--and hope to keep it for 3 or 4 years. The usual lifespan of the battery--at least for me. I would rather opt for a new shaver than replacing the battery. I would recommend this product to anyone who likes the ease and convenience of an electric shaver.

  224. I have been using this shaver for over 1 year with no problems, comfortable shave, easy to handle, good charge, & reliable. Have used other electric razors, remington and norelco, and this is the best value I could find, worth every penny!<br /><br />Original blades still sharp and going strong, shaving every week day, and gets the extra weekend growth fine, just takes a little longer. Works fine on the neck too. I am probably average as far as hair and skin sensitivity, don't move over skin too fast and finish before the blades heat up so no razor burn.<br /><br />It is quiet and doesn't sound like it is running very fast. As far as revolutions per second, I think the rating system is flawed for all rotarys, so 18,000 rpms divided by 3 heads = 6,000 each under no load in a vacuum may be possible, but not in my bathroom. Regardless the shave is just fine for this razor.<br /><br />A battery charge indicator would be nice but I just run it till it quits and easily get 2 to 3 weeks out of a charge. It does slow down a bit for the last few shaves before the battery dies, so I do know when it needs a charge.<br /><br />No problem with the storage compartment and cleaning, just rinse the heads every couple weeks and let them air dry. The trimmer works fine too, still sharp, and I expect to get at least 2 years out of the blades before needing replacement.<br /><br />I would definitely recommend this razor.

  226. This Norelco 8240XL shaver was a replacement for my Norelco 7885XL. It's shaving quality is excellent. I found it easier and faster to shave because the entire head more easily conformed to the shape of my face. The case provided holds the shaver but not the charging cord. If charged, it's very compact and takes little room in a suitcase if you don't need the cord along. The charge lasted for about two weeks of daily shaves. I found the trimmer to be adequate, but not as sharp as the trimmer on my previous 7885XL. There is no indication of the percentage of charge left in the device. It will just stop running at which time you use the cord for the rest of the shave, and then let it recharge, which takes only about an hour. Overall I'd give this a 4-star rating based on its price/performance and ease of use benefits.
  227. I've shaved electric for going on 30 years now and had always used Braun shavers. I received this Norelco as a gift and have used it for three months. I have to use a blade razor to get those.<br /><br />I'm in the market for a foil shaver.

I am getting a good shave in about 20% less time and I can get a full week, or more, of shaves on a charge as compared to half that with my last Norelco.
  236. Great shave! The only thing I miss is the 'time remaining' indicator. For more than twice the price I could have that also - so I can live without it. I've used it for a month now & haven't had to recharge it yet. Much better shave than my 12 year-old Norelco that it replaced (the battery finally wasn't holding a full charge). I'm happy!
  237. I bought this for my husband b-day. He tried it and love it. Worth what I paid for! From now on, rather spend money on this one than the cheap brand!
  238. I am totally pleased with the performance of this razor. Charges quickly and shaves close. The only drawback is there is no stand for the razor and the bottom is not flat for it to stand up. So it lays on it side, big deal. This is my 3rd Norelco (over a period of 30 years) and I am as pleased with this one as I was with the others.
  239. It is my third shaver on same brand. Nice quality and easy to operate. Great shipping from Amazon.com, taking about 4 days to deliver.
  240. The top bracket that holds in the blades on my old Norelco 8151XL broke, so I went to a local store and bought the 8240 as an emergency replacement. It works well enough, but the motor seems a little anemic. I have some disappointments with the product: No stand to hold the razor when I'm not shaving. There's no low battery warning - it just stops running while you're shaving. Of course, you're supposed to wait for this to happen before you recharge it. I bought a repair part for my old razor, and will go back to using it. I'll save this one as a backup.
  241. After 65 years of using a double edge I was satisfied with this medical mandatory change to an electric razor. It is working quite well.
  242. This is the third Norelco electric razor that I have had and it is the smoothest I've ever used. My only complaint is that its missing a battery level indicator; this means that when I'm planning to take a trip, I always charge the battery.
  243. This razor was purchased for my husband who loves the razor and is very satisfied with it, the only thing that he misses on it is the \\"low battery\\" indicator. It gives him as very smooth and close shave. Thank you.
  244. I used a Norelco for years, after suffering a lot of razor burn from foil type razors. A year ago I switched from my trusty Philips Norelco to a Remington rotary that had two concentric rings of cutting areas and got a faster shave but it tended to bite, especially in the lip area around the mouth. Ouch! This new 8240 is still running on the original charge after 12 days of shaving, and provides the best shave ever, with no razor burn, and no biting. I bought it only because it incorporates a LiIon battery instead of the old nickel cadmium variety that failed in a couple of years, but I'm surprised and extremely pleased by the improved overall quality of this new model as well as the shave it provides. This model represents a lot of subtle improvements by Philips! Some may complain about the lack of a low battery indicator, but it will recover so quickly that this is a mute point: it really doesn't matter because you can plug it in, do something else for 5 minutes then pick it up and shave. I highly recommend this Norelco!
  245. This is my third Norelco shaver and it is improved over the other two. It gives a good shave and is easy on the skin. The ultimate telling point will be how long it lasts. The other two Norelcos have lasted about 4 years. The first on the swithch broke and the second on the battery died. The only negative I have found on the this new shaver is that it does not have an indication when the battery is low.
  246. Let me say that I usually just by a electric razor and after about 2 years buy a new one. However, I have never replaced blades. I don't think this is what is intended, but it hasn't hurt anything. I have an old remington that I picked up on clearance in the same style as this Norelco. I normally work 4 days a week and let the facial hair grow for the weekend. Basically this gets used 4days a week. With the remington with 3 year old blades I would get some pull, but it would do a quick job. Now with this one it shaves closer, some pull near the mustache, but I have to spend over twice the time to get rid of 3 day old stubble compaired to my old razor. I have also noticed that at the very top, where the base pivot part connects to the top plastic blade shroud, there is some overlap that catches my nostrils when shaving near the nose. Not sure that I traided up this time. I regret throwing away the container! Stuck with it now and wishing I would have just got replacement blades. Note: It is quiet and shaves close, just not quickly.
  247. Highlights: Quieter than most other electrics shavers I have used Decently close shave Down-sides: Not really feasible if you are trying to shave around facial hair (eg mustache or beard) Sometimes hairs can get pulled when trying to shave if they are left too long
  248. Pros:<br /><br />- Easy to rinse, hair chamber is waterproof and has built-in drainage so you can just run it under hot water<br /><br />- Very close shave, can't feel stubble in any direction after shaving with this*<br /><br />- Trimmer powerful enough to handle sideburns and if you fall behind on shaving, trims down thick beard-hair before using regular side<br /><br />Cons:<br /><br />- Three-ring blade system really isn't all that special, more of a marketing gimmick because all three rings are actually done with one blade unit, so the rings don't move independently. This makes the shaver no more contour-following than any other.<br /><br />- Shaver tugs and pinches if you get behind on shaving. A lot. Have to use the trimmer first, then shave if you go a few days. Since the \\"precision cutting system\\" is supposed to handle long hair, it loses a star for that.<br /><br />- The battery is very picky about how you charge and use it, and very unforgiving if you are loose with their rules. Mine was shot in the first 6 months. You aren't supposed to leave it plugged in after it's fully charged, but i don't have a good block of time to sit and stare at the charge light so had to charge it overnight or while at work. I took the second star for this.<br /><br />- Could have just been me, but the one week i was at a conference and used this every morning to be as clean-shaven as possible through the whole time, my face was hyper-irritated by the end. Could've just been my face and beard-type so i'm not taking stars off for that, but be advised.<br /><br />*Caution: the closeness of this shave would probably be desired by most, but with rough, curly beards like mine it actually lead to a lot of ingrown hairs, a bad enough problem that i had to stop using electric razors.
  249. Very good shaver, smooth ,shaves well, quiet, good life on batteries. Order showed up in 3 days. Web site easy to use and compare other products thanks, jar
  250. My husband is very difficult to shop for. I researched like crazy for him for Christmas. This one stood out to me and I bought it hoping for the best. He LOVES it! Here are a few reasons why: Close shave, fast, gets everything (he has a tough beard). We highly recommend this and it is a great price!
  251. ultra modern, light weight, sleek design.<br /><br />The sturdy packaging may require a box-knife to open.<br /><br />...a few words from Dad: \\"The Philips Norelco 8240XL, Rechargeable, Triple header, Cordless/Cord Razor can only be used dry. After the first 12-hour charge, it is ready to go. It is easy to use with a handle grip that is comfortable. The 8240XL shaves close after several passes with it's face contour following floating head cutting system.<br /><br />It has a spring-released pop-up trimmer for moustache and sideburn trimming. The trimmer cuts well, though a bit noisy, in my opinion.<br /><br />Clean-up is easy with the cleaning brush or rinse under the faucet using the razor head release button.<br /><br />Accessories include a cleaning brush, carrying pouch, protective cap, and AC power cord. I found the instruction guide well-written and easy to follow.\\"<br /><br />17 days of shave-time on one charge!<br /><br />Dad, you look Fantastic! --Katharena Eiermann, 2008
  252. SHAVING BACKGROUND I used to use the Gillette Mach3. Then I upgraded to the Fusion (for free). I wasn't completely satisfied and wanted to go back to the Mach3, but before I did, I came across Wet Shaving. Wet Shaving with the Double Edge Safety Razor irritated less and gave me a closer shave. The classics - who would've thought. I never looked back to cartridge based shaving. At one point I did buy an electric shaver. It was a foil head one. I didn't stay with it for long because it worked even worse than this one. After torturing my face a few times, I returned it. I always thought that this three head design would have worked better, so wanted to try it. FACIAL BACKGROUND I think I have sensitive skin. My hair grows from my ears toward my chin, then down to my Adam's apple and then away from it. I don't have straight hair. A single hair grows like a bridge. If I let a beard form, it will look curly, especially around my neck. I don't like to grow it because it pricks my face, so I need a easy, non-irritating shaving system to shave every day or two. ELECTRIC CHRONICLE I struggled with the ridiculous packaging. A Sealed plastic package within a paper package that isn't easy to open either. And there is no easy way to cut open the package without the risk of cutting yourself - and it would be easiest to do with a box cutter (but who has one), not a scissor. I almost sliced my thumb on the plastic packaging. 21 July 2008 Shave 1 - The razor shaved well above my chin, but there are still large patches of hair that remained untouched below my chin. My face, especially the neck, is irritated to the point of stinging, even after applying a moisturizer. Shave 2 - The patches of hair below my chin are now significantly smaller. My face is irritated. My neck stings. The trimmer on the back isn't great for shaping sideburns since it doesn't trim close enough to the skin. So far the problem seems to be that the shaver doesn't glide acrossmy face - it meets heavy resistance from a clean face and the move against the grain. Shave 3 - Instead of washing my face, I apply some Lectric Shave, which takes care of the gliding problem. There are no longer patches of hair below my chin; instead, just some lonely hairs. My face isn't as irritated, but my neck still stings a little. Shave 4 - Same as Shave 3. I've noticed some ingrown hairs on my neck. Shave 5 - The razor shaved well above my chin, but there are large patches of hair that remained untouched below my chin. My face feels irritated. 28 July 2008 Shave 6 - Similar to Shave 5. The razor shaved well above my chin, but there are large patches of hair that remained untouched below my chin. My face feels slightly irritated. Shave 7 - Same as Shave 5. Shave 8 - About 3 days after Shave 7. There are a few lonely hair above my chin that didn't make it and big patches of untouched hair below my chin. My face feels irritated. I had originally planned on going for the three weeks. However, during my last shave as I was shaking the water loose from the shaver, I must have held it wrong and the head fell to the floor with the grills and blades separated. Because the manual said if the blades were swapped, I would lose my progress, I have decided to quit. CONCLUSION I shaved for almost two weeks, torturing my face. In the end, nothing changed. Electric shaving is faster to use than a blade and cleanup is easy because you only need to run it under hot water once when finished. However, the blade shaves closer, doesn't irritate my face, and has a more complete shave. After walking around with an unclean shave for two weeks, I can't wait to return to Wet Shaving.
  253. If I shave in the morning, I'll have the makings of a five-o'clock shadow in the afternoon. I've always used electric razors, and I've used wet/dry, single blade, and rotary blade. This Philips Norelco, might just be the best I've ever used. It gives a clean, close shave that lasts almost all day. The quiet motor at first seems like its hardly working, but it efficiently trims my beard. The battery holds a charge for a long time. Shaving below the jaw and around the neck can be tedious, but I've never had a razor behave otherwise. The trimmer, however, does not work well at all and is the only problem I had.
  254. I've used a few Norelco razors, and every one that comes out is a little better than the previous model. The three round blades mold to your face so comfortably, and get every angle imaginable that you'll have trouble adjusting to any other razor after using it.<br /><br />The only thing keeping this from a full five stars is cleaning it. It can be a real hassle taking it apart and getting in every nook to clean it. With other razors on the market that clean themselves, this is a tedious annoyance for such a great little machine.
  255. Having not used an electric shaver for nearly 30 years, I was interested in how much they had improved (if any) in that time. This Norelco is pretty good as electrics go. You are required to do a 12 hour charge before using the shaver to fully condition the battery (also after periods of one month or more of non-use). After that, the shaver is supposed to recharge in as little as 1 hour. I have yet to run it down enough to require a recharge, though, so I can't comment on how accurate that is. The shaver feels good in the hand and is easy to move and control. However, with its round heads, it is problematic to sculpt a beard or mustache. This shaver is pretty much for those who go completely clean shaven. The pop-up trimmer is just about useless, as it does not lock into place, and moves when you put any pressure on it. I took an unexpected divot out of my beard because it is so flaky. I recommend that you just ignore the trimmer in considering this shaver. The trimmer dropped this from a 4 to a 3 star review. It is pretty badly designed. Needless to say, electrics just don't give as close a shave as a blade, period. That said, I was able to get a clean \\"looking\\" shave easily with this shaver, although you could obviously feel the difference by touch. For quick touch-ups, however, this works well, and I find myself using it more and more for that. Since I have a goatee and mustache, there are many parts of my face where this just doesn't work. I still have to trim around the goatee with a blade or smaller trimmer (I tried a Norelco trimmer set, too, with mixed results.), so this shaver cannot fill all my shaving needs. It is good for large blocks of open face or head only. Construction seems good, although the head seems kind of light weight. Lots of plastic parts, but a good, solid feel in general. The rotary cutters and related assembly can be replaced (annually, per the instructions). The heads track well over uneven skin for a consistent shave. Directions are included for several levels of cleaning, and they are clear and concise. If you are clean-shaven on face or head, this could be a very useful shaver for you. If you have more sculpted facial hair, it will be less useful. I will not be giving up my blades for this, although it has become useful for quick touch-ups.
  256. This shaver does one thing and one thing only: shaves your beard. Luckily, it does it well and--this is rather important for me--reasonably quietly. The quiet part comes in handy when you have a girlfriend sleeping a few feet down the hall who has the good fortune of being able to sleep in longer than you, and you'd rather not make her cranky by waking her up with the grinding whir of a loud shaver. This one also holds a charge for a good long time (I can easily get a week out of one charge), and then, when the battery does run low, it re-charges very quickly (a couple of hours does it, rather than the 6 or 8 hours required by some older models). The reason this little baby does not rate five stars is because it does nothing else: no trimmer for sideburns, no closeness adjustments, no attachments of adjustments of any kind. You have two options with this shaver: on or off. It is so simple in fact that I find their description \\"Men's Shaving System\\" sort of funny. This is a system? But, if you're looking for a nothing fancy, no-frills electric razor, this one does the job.
  257. This shaver gives an excellent cut, and is easy to use. It is difficult to clean properly as the parts to be cleaned, unlike previous models, do not detach easily.
  258. I like the heft, styling and feel. This Norelco seems well-built and is a good deal quieter than my old one. I like that it can be cleaned under water but regret that there is no stand. Leaving it lying out with the blade compartment open to dry would seem to invite damage. While the battery life is so far as advertised (with as many as 17 shaves after being fully charged), I wish that it had a light to indicate when the battery has been fully charged and when it is close to needing a recharge. Here's one surprise--it doesn't seem to cut as close as my old Norelco, or it requires more time and attention to do so. I don't have a heavy beard, like to think that my new Norelco still makes me presentable, and it's so much easier and less expensive than a razor, I'm very satisfied! At $80, I'd make the same purchase again!
  259. When I first got my Norelco, I thought it didn't shave as close as my old Norelco, but I think it was just a different \\"feel\\" from the shaving surface of the razor. What I really love is the clean under the faucet feature of this razor. I think it makes for better day to day use, and is sure easier to clean than my old one!
  260. The electric razor I have had for 15 years finally died and I bought a very cheap replacement. It is horrible and I wish I could take it back - it does not cut my beard!   261. I am not a spring chicken and therefore go way back with the Norelco line of electric shavers however this 8240XL steals the bacon for me. Simply put I am hugely happy that for among many reasons to bring up, this shaver performs closer than a blade.Buying blades today is a massive investment that will mirror an equity play by year's end. I have spoken to men who purchase the bag of disposables but you better cost them out as well before you conclude that they are an economical strategy. To put things in its proper perspective, men's shaving methods are trial and error. There are individuals who simply will never be able to go electric because of neck irritation or the idea that their beard is the wrong texture for a machine shave. That is why blade shaving is much more wide spread but not as convenient, quick and really cheap as the Norelco whose expense is a head purchase which comes up very seldom. I had purchased a very fine brand before this Norelco but it was a flat head electric. The area under the jaw is very difficult to shave and for me the flat head could not handle the slope. The Norelco, with pivoting heads and a wide surface can capture this area of your face hands down as it glides over it. My shave today was so impressively close that at midnight I still could have gone to the Sadie Hawkins Dance with a clean look. This whole thing is a caveat emptor proposition so all I can tell you is that I am very pleased with the Norelco 8240XL. Investigate the benefits for you, my razor came with some kind of trial provision. Good Luck. Jay Adler

  268. I've been using Philips-Norelco razors for many years, since long before Philips changed the name from simply Norelco, and this one gives the best shave yet, a shave indistinguishable from a wet razor shave. But, the fact that this razor has no \\"Low Battery\\" warning light is most disconcerting. The razor just stops, and you think something has gone wrong with it. A phone call to Philips Norelco dispels the notion: it stops, you plug it in, finish your shave, and let it continue to charge. No sweat--except the first time it happens. Aside from this, it's a great razor.
  269. I can't believe there are so many positive reviews for this awful product. If you're the kind of guy that has to shave every 2 days DO NOT BUY it. I bought it brand new and it pulled my beard and made me bleed.
  270. I Bought this because read that blades rotate at 13,000 rpm and the cheapie Norelco + Remington's I tried rotated at much lower speeds and for me was the main problem and not because taking longer is the problem but in the same way that a vacuum with too little suction would be with not taking too long as the problem but rather unable to do the job properly at all. So having happily owned an 800 series Norelco from 15 yrs ago (simiarly priced when adjusted for inflaion + comparable product for it's time period) I bought this 8240XL because it said 'Speed XL' with of course SPEED being my main concern. So here is my reveiw: If you don't remove the blades after every use and rinse them the shaver does not do a good job so that needs to be done and although raiser can be rinsed under water for easy cleaning you'll want to pull out those 3 blades and individually rinse them which isn't too hard to do. Motor is quiet, heads pivot in a couple different ways and shaving surface is good and the right size. Ergonomics and style are good. What I find to be particuarly worth noting though is when running it on battery power (cordless) the job it does is just OK and perhaps a little underwhelming BUT plug it in and the extra 5% or so more power that A/C power gives makes all the difference bringing a SO-SO shaver up to quite a good one definately worth recomending. So in short, if you NEED to use this as a cordless shaver all the time would recomend looking into something a little more powerful but if you don't mind plugging it in you'll find it performs noticeably better and for me makes all the difference.

  285. This is the best electric razor I've ever used and I'm very impressed! I'm a Norelco fan. I don't like blades. I've used foil shavers in the past from Remington and Braun, and they always irritated my skin, missed hairs, and never shaved my neck well. The first time I used a Norelco rotary shaver I got a close shave with very little irritation and I've never looked back.<br /><br />This is an upgrade from a 4 year old Norelco 6423LC corded shaver which was a low end model. The old one did a fine job and served me well, but this one shaves me closer with less effort and and irritation. The pivoting head and and 3 shaving tracks are a big improvement. I could care less that it doesn't have a charge indicator or low battery warning. Another influence in picking this model was that it uses a lithium-ion battery which means the motor provides constant power and won't slow down the closer you get to the end of the charge. They also don't suffer from the memory effect of the older technology of nickel cadium batteries in Norelco's lower end models. Just be sure to charge it for a full 12 hours the first time like it says in the manual to break it in and you'll get the best battery life. It's also nice to be able to wash the heads out under the faucet to keep it clean, very nice!<br /><br />As to the negatives, I've found none so far! I read the reviews before I purchased and there are far more positive than negative on here. As to the negative comments, I'll say rotary shavers aren't for everyone, just as foil shavers aren't for me. We all have different faces and beard types. You just have to figure out which one works the best for you. If you're a rotary man, then I don't see how you could go wrong with this shaver. I'm in love with mine. Excellent purchase!<br /><br />A helpful tip if you want to keep your blades nice and sharp. Go to Youtube and search for a video called, \\"How To Sharpen An Electric Shaver Norelco Philips Rotary Kind Using Basic Household Items\\". It involves using a ceramic plate or coffee cup and is very simple to do. I tried it out on my old shaver and it breathed new life into it. It shaves like brand new now without having to buy replacement heads for it.es using a ceramic plate or coffee cup and is very simple to do. I tried it out on my old shaver and it breathed new life into it. It shaves like brand new now without having to buy replacement heads for it.
  286. A quiet, smooth shave. This shaver has no problem picking up whiskers. No irritation and a very satisfactory shave.
  287. Great razor.....great price... fast delivery...
  288. I've used Norelco electric razors for over 30 years and loved all my previous ones. But I wish I had never bought this model. It is very rough on sensitive skin, does not shave very close at all and pulls on whiskers many times. I should've returned it right away but I thought I could get used to it but I never have.
  289. I have only used this shaver for about two weeks and it is still on the first charge. I am very impressed with how fast and well it cuts. It is about 3-4 times faster than my previous rather old Norelco shaver. The thing that I find the nicest is how quiet the unit operates. It can hardly be heard yet it is faster and seems more powerful than my former shaver. Also the trimmer works well. I highly recommend this product.
  290. I normally don't write reviews, and although I have owned three previous Norelco shavers, THIS IS THE BEST SHAVER I HAVE EVER OWNED. My last \\"higher level\\" Norelco died, and I was hesitant to buy another, especially with a \\"lower model number\\". But this model is a gem. It is quiet, efficient and shaves quickly and easily. I highly recommend this shaver. I may even buy a second one to keep in my car (of course to shave when I am not driving). Great product -- reasonable cost. Buy it!
  291. I bought this Norelco shaver to replace a similiar, but older, model that I had used for several years. Shave is great.
  292. This is the third Norelco electric razor I've owned and the worst by far. The first was a corded L1118, which although heavy and bulky, worked very well. My second Norelco, which I still have, is a 5801XL. It was, and still is, an excellent razor. I bought the 8240XL last December but did not use it until March 2011. It didn't take long to learn to hate this razor. There are three major flaws with this model, as far as I am concerned: 1. The release button to open the cutting head assembly is too easy to activate. I have accidentally hit this button any number of times while shaving, which caused the head assembly to pop open while the razor is on. 2. The hinge which connects the head assembly to the razor body is a friction-fit design which allows the head unit to detach all too easily. I choose not rinse my razor but tap on the head assembly to clean it. It is a given that the head assembly will fall off each time unless I hold it in place, and even that does not always work. Also, I do not bang on the head assembly, but gently tap it. 3. The locking mechanism which is supposed to keep the cutting heads secured in the head assembly is too easy to accidentally unlock when cleaning the razor. I have had it open at least three times while I was cleaning the razor, allowing all the cutters to fall into the sink. Of course, there is no way to make sure the right pieces go back together, so shaving quality immediately suffers. Norelco even recommends not mixing up the cutters and the foils for this very reason. The locking mechanism in the 5801 has to be pushed in and turned to release the cutting heads; it is an almost perfect system and works very well, as opposed to the one in the 8240. If I had it to do over, I would not buy this razor again, and I do not recommend it for the reasons listed above. It is poorly designed, and Norelco took a step backward as far as I am concerned. The 5801 is a much better razor, and I only bought the 8240 because buying new blades for an old razor is not a good investment after the first time. Yes, the 8240 is quiet and it worked well until it came apart the first time, but those are all the positives I will give this razor. I will look to another brand next time, unless Norelco makes some major changes in these razors.
  293. Excellent product very fast shave, I now have two of these, and will purchase again if necessary. I believe<br />it is the very best model.
  294. I am very happy with the purchase of the Norelco 8240xl as it performs well and is a top value for the price. I definitely would recommend this product to others.
  295. This unit is the 3rd Norelco that I have owned. So far, the unit works well. Snags a little bit if I hold it incorrectly. I purchased this because the others batteries died and it cost almost as much for new rechargeable batteries as a new unit. I do miss one thing. The old unit had a series of led indicators for battery life. This has none. So, it runs, or you need to recharge it. Would I buy it again, yes based on the short time I've used it.
  296. Very quite and smooth. Close shave without pressure and excellent recharge time. Great value.
  297. Nice shaver. No complaints really. A perfect size, easy to clean, good battery life between charges. Occasionally may miss a hair or two but I am satisified with the purchase.
  298. Yes I just read the glowing reviews by many people who loved this shaver .The reason is ,it's new!! therefore it has to be decent or you have 60 days to send it back.Too bad they don't give you six months.First let me say I consider myself a bit of a Norleco expert .Why do I say that? I have been using Norelco since the late 1940's when they came out with the single head shaver ,the Philishave.Years later came the dual head until they started the triple head with 1 row of cutters .Today the triple head with 2 rows of cutters for more money just is not worth it.<br /><br />Now I have tried most shavers over the years ,Ronson ,Remington ,Schick ,Braun and Norelco .Now let me say ,they all suck with maybe Norelco a hair better than Braun .In fact my wife bought me a Braun for Xmas 2 years ago,a disappointment, so to get a decent shave I use the Braun then mop up with the Norelco.I bought this shaver June 2010 to use at my summer home ,so I used it for 3 months in 2010 and 6 weeks in 2011.The shaver is damn lousy .I keep going over hair on my cheek which it wont cut ,over and over ,even after useing preshave lotion .I thoroughly cleaned the unit in May which improved my shave a little .But now im ready to take a hammer to it .Folks, Norelco's used to last 2 years and then you took it to a Norelco store for a cleaning and tuneup and you would get maybe another few years .Now if you get 3 months rejoice ,you are due for a new one ,just don't spend $80 for this ,buy the $39.95 one with 1 row of cutters and throw it out in a few months.Yes I used an Amazon coupon worth $10 and bought the $39.95 one for $29.95 a couple of dollars more than replacement blades.Norelco is the best of the worst.<br /><br />I congratulate myself not paying $100-$200 for their Artic which sounds to me like money thrown out ,after all it's their lousy blades which don't last ,sort of like ink catridges .One thing I notice they don't mention self sharpening blades anymore,maybe thats why their blades don't last!!<br /><br />It's too bad so many users are giving this shaver 4 or 5 stars ,wait 3 months they will be singing another tune .<br /><br />Feb 11th 2012<br /><br />I read an interesting comment on Amazon ,after people complaining about the high cost of replacement blades.He said take the screens off ,get a mirror and put a little saliva on the mirror .Then run the shaver for 15 seconds the cutters pressed against the mirror ,this will hone the cutters.however it's a bit awkward the cutters tend to drop off ,but was able to do it.It appears that seems to work somewhat ,but I'm not sure whether the fact that I cleaned the heads might have improved my shave or was it the mirror.Time will tell.too bad so many users are giving this shaver 4 or 5 stars ,wait 3 months they will be singing another tune . Feb 11th 2012 I read an interesting comment on Amazon ,after people complaining about the high cost of replacement blades.He said take the screens off ,get a mirror and put a little saliva on the mirror .Then run the shaver for 15 seconds the cutters pressed against the mirror ,this will hone the cutters.however it's a bit awkward the cutters tend to drop off ,but was able to do it.It appears that seems to work somewhat ,but I'm not sure whether the fact that I cleaned the heads might have improved my shave or was it the mirror.Time will tell.
  299. The shaver does a much better job than my 10 yr old Norelco (my guess is my blade had really dulled over time). This new unit is much lighter and seems to work well. The only drawback - my old shaver had a countdown timer estimating the remaining charge. I miss that.
  300. I just received this razor as an upgrade to the Philips Norelco 7110X which I had been using for the past 19 months. While one would expect this razor to perform better given its list price (approximately double what the 7110X is currently), I was frankly surprised by how much better it is in almost every regard. I previously reviewed the 7110X, so if you want to see what I found lacking in that razor the review is available under that product listing. As to the superior qualities of the 8240XL, they are: 1. Shaves are closer and do not require as many passes over the same area. I still don't think it gives me as good of a shave as a manual razor and shaving cream, but I've never found an electric shaver that could compete with a manual razor in terms of closeness of shave. Sometimes I prefer the convenience of the electric shaver, however, so that's why I use both methods on occasion. 2. Feels more solid in the hand. 3. While it isn't quiet, it sounds less annoying when it's running. The only serious problem I've encountered so far is with respect to charging the razor. The manual indicates it may take 12 hours to fully charge the razor before the first use. I had mine plugged in for over 15 hours and the light on the razor indicated that it was not yet fully charged. I decided to keep the razor plugged in and use it. After I completed shaving, the charging light briefly indicated it was fully charged but then started indicating it was still charging again. I decided to unplug the razor anyway. I re-checked the manual. Unfortunately, it's written to cover three different models, so not everything in the manual pertains to this specific model. Even so, the drawings indicate charging lights on the razor that simply don't correspond to what's on the actual unit (for example, I don't see anywhere on the unit that the word \\"Full\\" would illuminate), and there's no indication in the manual that these drawings only pertain to other units. Strange. Before owning my Philips Norelco 7110X, I had also owned another Norelco model (more similar in quality to this razor than the 7110X) and some other models from Braun. I've generally been pleased with Norelco electric razors, and this one is another winner.
  301. This electric razor gave a good shave, but after two years of use the shaving head frame broke, which was a real disappointment. That shouldn't have happened on a razor as expensive as this one; I expected better quality.
  302. This shaver gives me a very nice close shave fast! Even shaves well when I skip shaving one day. It has a pop up trimmer. I am very glad I got it. The instructions mention using the shaver for 2 to 3 weeks to become accustomed to the shaver. I think this may be for someone who never has used an electric shaver before. It gives a very nice shave right from the start. I feel this rotary type of shaver gives a much better shave and is easier to use than a foil type.
  303. It works but seems cheap. I 've been using it for awhile and it seems ok. I've had no real problems. The charging is fine and shave is not as close as I would like. I'm keeping it until it breaks
  304. Once again I'm giving a shaver review, and once again I have to say that I've yet to find an electric shaver that can either beat or come close to the \\"good ole water razor\\" brand. If you want or need a very close \\"baby\\" shave (say the military or such where your face will be closely looked at a few times a day, then do yourself a favor and don't look at electric shavers, but go with the water/razor brands). With that out of the way, lets get on with this review.<br /><br />This is a good middle line Norelco shaver. There are no thrills in that you cannot adjust the cut height, it's not one of those more expensive \\"cool\\" looking ones that Norelco sells (if that appeals to you) and most important is that there is no low battery indicator. So that if you're like me and just keep on using it not thinking that it's not been charged, it'll just go out while shaving.<br /><br />However I've found that I was able to get around 12-15 shaves out of one charge. So that's not bad.<br /><br />It's easy to clean.<br /><br />Not loud at all, compared to many others I've tried (even more expensive)! If you have someone sleeping right close, they won't even hear it!<br /><br />You do need to give it a good charge before using (overnight or such), so don't expect to open it and charge it for five minutes then use it.<br /><br />I'll say that if you have any acne, be CAREFUL as this will give you a good cut! Boy did I bleed after being careless and running right over a pimple that must of had skin or such sticking out.<br /><br />IMHO this shaver would make a good gift for that gentleman needing a first shaver or someone who does not like a lot of \\"extras\\" to fool around with on the razor. It's basic, does a good job, not a lot to fiddle around with.<br /><br />I'll say that if you take care of it, keep it clean, and charged it will last you many years.
  305. Like any electric razor, this one takes some time to get used to if you're used to a regular razor. My first time using this, I was less than enthused. I gave it time, however, and found it to be a very effective shaver. It charges quickly and lasts for some time; I've only had to charge it once since I received it. It's also quite light compared to an electric razor I owned a few years past. And there you have it: It performs quite well, holds a charge, and looks/feels stylish to boot.
  306. Very nice stylish looking razor. This razor is very quiet and it cuts close every time without much pressure. I like the contour shape
  307. While I understand this shaver was designed for men, this review is from a woman's perspective. It was for my partner, but he didn't care for it, and despite my cajoling, refused to endure the 2 weeks recommended in the instructions for adjusting from blade to electric. I myself have used mens' Norelco shavers in the past, and I do like the flexibility of a tidy, dry shave, especially when traveling, but you never get as close a cut as with a blade razor, and this is no exception. It's handy to be able to shave in the car (not driving, of course), and it did a nice job on my legs (though my leg hair isn't very coarse), but was awful on my underarms. Aside from the rinse feature, which is nice, I didn't find any improvement in use or shave over the last norelco I bought 10 years ago. I do have to note that the moustache/beard trimmer is great for quick bangs touch-ups, but overall, I wouldn't recommend it for women.
  308. My experience with the Norelco Speed 8240 has been quite good so far. It gives a pretty clean shave, but at sometimes, it doesn't do a great job with cutting hair in the neck area below the chin. Other than that, I am very satisfied with it. Another note, the battery life on this product is tremendous because I haven't had to charge it for a little more than 3 weeks (and I use it everyday).
  309. *THIS REVIEW HAS BEEN UPDATED. SEE BELOW.*<br /><br />I bought this shaver to replace my 5-year-old Philips HQ7830. Yes, this 8240 is a pretty good shaver. Compared to other shavers I've had in the past (Remington, Panasonic, Braun), it gives a reasonably smooth shave and has a good trimmer. It is fairly light and is comfortable to hold and maneuver. It is also much quieter than the old Philips it replaces.<br /><br />However, this new shaver disappoints me in several ways: In careful side-by-side tests over a month, the new shaver with its fancy three-ring heads shaved me no better than the old one's single-ring \\"7 Series\\" heads that are 2-1/2 years old. In fact, I think it might be pulling my skin a little bit more, and I seem to have more ingrown beard hairs than before.<br /><br />Also, the new shaver's lithium-ion battery doesn't last as long as the old nickel-cadmium battery of the old shaver (which I maintained very carefully). Worse yet, the new shaver's battery dies very suddenly, without warning -- there's no battery level light or gauge, and only a barely perceptible slowdown in blade speed shortly before it stops. If you're not with your charger and near an outlet, you're out of luck.<br /><br />The old shaver sealed the motor spindles from water, so you could rinse the shaver and shake it out. The new one channels water down past the motor spindles and through the shaver body, so it drips out the bottom around the charger plug contacts. I worry about a potential short circuit when plugging in the charger when the shaver is wet, and also that the interior channels might eventually clog with hair residue and mineral deposits if water dries inside the machine. I hope the usually careful Philips engineers have thought about these issues.<br /><br />In summary, I would recommend this shaver to someone buying their first Philips. But if you have an old Philips, consider keeping it. A new one might be no better, and maybe even worse.<br /><br />*UPDATE 16 June2012: Several days ago, this shaver's battery died for good, and rather suddenly at that. Now the battery barely makes it through one shave. This is very disappointing for a shaver that is only one year and 10 months old, and has been very well cared for. Moreover, the battery is not user-replaceable, so I'll have to buy a new one... probably a Braun.
  310. This is a fine product, and comes at a reasonable price. The only feature it misses, but is available in higher-priced models, is the light that tells you when it needs charging. No big deal because if it runs out of juice a quick 3-minute charge will get you enough power for a shave, and then you can give it a full charge. Shaves well, and a lot quicker than my old (5 years) Norelco. I like it, and I'd buy it again.
  311. Refer to the review by Jon Norris: this is almost exactly what my experience is, so I'd say this is a useful review. I'm not quite as thrilled, however, since this is a pricey shaver (I paid about $90 at target in Jan. 2009) compared to my prior Norelco (a 5025X - ~$29)), due, I'm assuming, to the three rows of blades per head. I don't think I have a particularly heavy beard (although not light), but the assertion by Norleco that you can get the whiskers off with one pass is bunk. It takes multiple passes on my neck and at my jaw to get the whiskers short enough that they don't fray my collar. As Mr. Norris observed, the ole' safety razor is not going away anytime soon. One thing I appreciate is how quiet this is - the previous one was quite loud. I also appreciate the fact you can rinse the heads under running water. Of note, the instructions point out that the blades are specific to the particular holder, so if you decide to clean the blades by taking them out and applying soap or alcohol to get rid of the various buildups of oil/hair/etc., be sure to do it one at a time so you replace each blade in the appropriate holder. I remain to be convinced that the extra money for the 3 blades per rotary is worth the extra cost. Perhaps if you shaved once a week it would be useful, but I shave once a day in the morning 5 days a week, and haven't found the extra blades save any time.
  312. I have owned many (New one every 3-4 years) Norelco razors over the past 30 years and I think this one may be the worst one I have ever owned. It does not give me as close a shave and it takes me longer to shave each morning. The longer shave time has led to a little bit of skin irritation. On the plus side the battery life is great I have been using it 3 weeks on its initial charge.
  313. I last used an electric in the early 70s when I was traveling a lot. I switched back to a blade as it was more comfortable and gave a lot better shave. I decided to give this a try because we are having intermittent water problems; some times it's there and sometimes not. It does a decent job and is much better than he previous one I tried. It is slow to get a good shave and is not as close as a blade but is more convenient. The trimmer is OK for evening sideburns and getting hair under your nose that the shaver can't reach but that's it. If you have a beard or mustache I would not recommend this as it can't do a precise trim at an edge nor is the trimmer really workable. Overall I give this a 4 because of the nearly limited trimmer, inability to do an edge,and because of the ecologically horrid user hostile packaging. There is no excuse for such badly designed unfriendly packaging. Even with a case knife I had problems due to the shape of the package. Some of my students who have bad arthritis would not be able to open the package without help.
  314. This is my third Norelco electric razor purchased since I started shaving over 40 years ago. They have all been very good razors and a good value for your money. They give a very good shave although not as good as a blade, naturally. This 8240xl is pretty quiet and lighter than the others I have owned. It is a basic, no bells and whistles, razor that has the triple blade in each head. It takes between one to two weeks before the heads get 'seated in' and your face gets accustomed to the razor before it starts to give an optimum shave. I prefer this type of razor over the electric \\"foil\\" types, it seems to give a better shave and isn't as rough on your skin. Also, I believe that Norelco has a 45 day trial period so you can return it if you aren't satisfied...can't beat that!!!

  321. I got this electric razor for my husband as a replacement for his old norelco and he really seems to like it. Things we've noticed that are nice improvements over his old one: the triple ringed heads - ie each of the three shaving heads has three rings of shaving within the head which makes shaving time much faster as it give him more coverage in the same amount of time as his single ring (triple head) shaver. it's so quiet I can hardly hear him shave in the morning - a great improvement over the super noisy one, especially since he gets up at the crack of dawn and I don't. we both love that this one allows you to rinse it clean under running water. As the primary home cleaner, I find that means a lot less mess in the sink every morning, ergo i don't have to clean up after him as much (woo hoo!). the shaver also holds a charge for what seems like forever. I think he only charges it once every two weeks or so. often he doesn't even have to take the charger with him when he travels which is nice because that's one more thing he doesn't have to worry about leaving behind. So if you're already a user of electric shavers, you will love this norelco model. it's a nice close shave, quiet, efficient, easy to clean. For those of you who prefer the close shave of a real razor... electric is just different. my husband hates real razors so this is absolutely the best solution for him.
  322. The concept is great. Maximize the number of shaver blades in contact with the skin at all times. Its smooth, quiet and easy to clean. I agree with those who say it does not cut as close a straight blade(s). I have yet to find an electric shaver that does. Never the less, if you keep it clean and lubricated it will give a close shave after several passes. No need for a mirror. No need for a bandage. It clearly was not designed for a moustache nor for a beard. The trimmer is only designed for a basic sideburn trim.

  325. For the past 25 years I have been using Remington foil shavers--most recently the Remington MS3 3700. I was always happy with them, but nothing mechanical lasts forever.   329. I got mine (in fact an 8245) from Costco, with a $25 immediate rebate. The package includes an extra set of replacement heads (Q9, costing over $30 separately). The shave is very efficint & soft, much better than the single row of blades in other models. The shaver is very light & user-friendly. It may be washed perfectly & safely under very hot water in a short time & dries very quickly. The initial battery charge of about 17 hrs. was good enough for 11 days. Successive charge takes about an hour or less. Unfortunately it lacks the low-charge light. So it suddenly stops in the middle of your shave, hence 4.5/5 stars. Otherwise it's my best shaver for almost 50 years !!

  334. IVE USED A BRAUN FOR 15 YEARS AND DECIDED TO FIND A NEW RAZOR AS THE CUTTING HEADS FOR MY BRAUN WERE GETTING HARDER TO LOCATE. THE KIDS BOUGHT THIS FOR ME FOR CHRISTMAS. I CHARGED ACCORDING TO DIRECTIONS. I HAD TO ASK MY WIFE IF SHE COULD HEAR THE MOTOR RUNNING IT WAS SO QUIET. THE PROBLEM IS: IT IS QUIET BECAUSE THE MOTOR IS BARELY TURNING. IT CUTS, BUT YOU KNOW THAT IT IS CUTTING BECAUSE IT IS PULLING ON THE WHISKERS. YOU HAVE TO GO OVER THE SAME AREA SEVERAL TIMES TO GET GOOD RESULTS. I DONT KNOW WHY THE MOTOR RUNS SO SLOWLY. AFTER READING SEVERAL OF THE NEGATIVE COMMENTS HERE, IT SEEMS TO BE THE NORM. IMAGINE USING A BLADE AND PULLING IT SLOWLY DOWN YOUR FACE. SAME FEELING. LOTS OF RASH ON THE TENDER AREAS AS WELL. ILL TAKE THIS BACK.
  335. I've been a \\"blade\\" man my entire life but the cost of using disposable razors has gotten cost prohibitive for a recently retired guy like me, so, after doing some online research, I took the plunge and purchased this 8240 Norelco. I figured that the cost was reasonable and I've always believed that \\"you get what you pay for.\\" That philosophy has served me well once again. Does it shave as close as a blade? No, but I didn't expect it to do so. It does provide a satisfactory shave (I don't have a heavy beard), is easy to clean, a once per week recharge of the battery has worked so far, it takes me less time to shave, saves water, saves energy (hot water), keeps my used disposable razors out of the landfill, and best of all it saves me money by reducing my shaving costs by an estimated 50% per year and that ain't too shabby. What's not to like? It's a keeper.
  336. I've been using Norelco shavers for almost 30 years now. I had Remington, Panasonic and Braun moments where I traded my face for a close shave but, in the end, the comfort of the Norelco's always won.<br /><br />I purchased the 8240XL about two weeks ago to replace my last one which I dropped. Here's my experience:<br /><br />- no quieter than any other Norelco I've owned. Its quiet but no different.<br />- assumed good battery life, have yet to charge it since its initial charge.<br />- decent ergonomics though a bit too light for me.<br />- build quality is down substantially from the last Norelco I purchased, though that was over 10 years ago. Drop this one and I assume I would pick it up in pieces.<br />- good comfort, best I've ever had. No matter where I shave, no burns.<br /><br />Now the bad news. This is the worst shaving electric razor I have ever owned. Perhaps I have a bad one but its pathetic. Yesterday I intentionally tried to get a decent shave by passing every part of my face 50 (fifty) times. Each time I would hear it chopping away on what was left from the last pass and after 50 passes it was still chopping away. If I need to go out at night, its another shave - I have never done this in the past as I'm not that picky about a smooth shave. Someone else mentioned it but this shaver appears underpowered.<br /><br />This one is being returned.

  338. I've been using Norelco electric shavers for more than 35 years. I like them and the 8240 provides the best shave of all the others I have owned. I am disapointed, however, at the very short battery life. I've owned this shaver for about 11 months and the battery died. I contacted Norelco and they promptly sent a replacement under the warranty, which is all well and fine. However, this is now the 4th Norelco I've had in about 5 years. My previous model battery died after a little more than a year. Norelco replaced it under the warranty but the replacement lasted just a little over a year. So, I've had 3 Norelco's in the past 5 years that have failed prematurely. This used to never be the case. I used to get 5 to 7 years out of a Norelco before the battery went. I hope the ppl at Norelco solve this problem because I'm running out of patience. Furthermore, once the warranty is expired, battery replacement is not user friendly, you can't just pop open the case and slide it out, it's designed to be replaced by a technician.<br /><br />I give this shaver 5 stars for shaving performance, one star for battery life and 5 stars for Norelco customer service, thus a weighted average of 3 stars.<br /><br />*****************<br />June, 2012 UPDATE<br />The warranty replacement shaver they sent me last June died this past weekend. I am extremely disappointed in the quality of Norelco shavers in recent years. It makes me sad because I really like the shaving performance. However, I am out of patience and have replaced the Norelco with a different brand.

I began using a 40 year old Braun sold by Abercrombie & Fitch to finish the shave. Time wore on and I was ready to toss it and buy another Braun foil shaver. I called Norelco and explained the problem. They apologized for the trouble I was having and quickly replaced it with a new one. They sent instructions, box and a mailing label to return the old one postage free. The new one is much better and I was warned only to charge it the recommended time. Over charging will wear out the battery quicker and the shave will be unsatisfactory due to the lack of proper power. Norelco stands behind it products!

  356. I've been happy with Norelco triple-head shavers a long time. The two previous ones I've owned each lasted for ten years or more until the Ni-Cad batteries would no longer hold a charge. The Speed XL model I bought in June 2009 has been performing well and has two advantages: the NiMh battery charge lasts much longer and cleaning is quick & easy with just a daily rinse under hot water, instead of dismantling the head and brushing the blades and combs. Room for improvement would be in the case provided, which is basically a sleeve that holds only the razor itself, not the separate charger. The specifications suggest that a full charge will last through 17 shaves (and it seems to do that), but, if travelling more than two weeks, the charger would have to be packed separately. I managed to squeeze the new shaver and charger into the old (larger) leather case that came with my previous Norelco model - a tight fit (previous models had only a cord, this one has an external transformer). This seems to be a good product and was available at a better price at Amazon.com than at Costco or at other online sites.
  357. The Norelco 8240XL is probably the best shaver I have ever purchased. It cuts close without any irritation to the skin and is so quiet you hardly realize it is running. Another bonus feature is that when you open the compartment with the blades, you can wash the heads without taking them out of the razor. Finally someone was thinking about the customer when they created this shaver! It is great right out of the box.
  358. My first impression was. because it was so quiet, I thought the battery needed charging, as it sounded like my old Norelco when it's battery was run down. I am sure I will learn this soon! Great cutting razor!
  359. I bought this shaver to replace another Norelco I owned that is 8 years old. This new one, the 8240xl, does a great job but it just seems to be not as well made as the previous one. It's lighter weight and feels like it flexes a bit when I hold it. There's also no readout to tell you how much batter life is left, which was a great feature on my old one. All in all, it does a good job, just not as solidly constructed as the old one.
  360. I like it now - after a few weeks of using it (not at first). I was used to the quadra action feel, but this razor feels and works fine now. It doesn't seem faster than my quadra action razor. Think about it: there is additional cutting area in the speed shaving system, but since the blades angular velocity is constant, the portion of blade near the blade center is moving more slowly (measured linearly) than the part of the blade at the perimeter. So a 50% increase in shaving area doesn't translate to a 50% faster shave, but somewhere in between 0% and 50%. The trimmer isn't nearly as good as that of my quadra action unit, especially at the ends - exactly where you need the most precise cut. So it loses a star for that.
  361. The new Philips Norelco (formerly known as just Norelco) 8240 comes to you in a box with a window that allows the shaver to be seen within its clear plastic packaging. You will need a sharp pair of scissors and/or a Rambo-style Bowie knife to hack thru this hard plastic covering and remove the shaver. Use extreme caution when doing so. Once you've defeated the packaging, you will find the sleek, gunmetal gray shaver; a protective cap; a small cleaning brush; a curly AC power cord; English/Spanish instruction booklet and a basic black zippered nylon case.<br /><br />The manual says you should plug the shaver in and let it charge for a full 12 hours before using it for the first time. The light on mine started blinking within the first hour, but I left it plugged in overnight anyway. When I tried the 8240 out the next morning, I was amazed at how quiet it is. My old Braun buzzes like a lawnmower, but this thing just whispers! The Norelco will supposedly go for up to 17 shaves before it needs recharging, and you're not supposed to recharge it until the battery is nearly depleted. Note that this model lacks the LOW BATTERY indicator light available on the 8250 and 8251 models.<br /><br />The overall design of this razor is quite impressive. The three shaver heads rock all around individually and the entire head assembly pivots on side bolts. This allows the cutters to hug your face while you shave for better results. Best of all, there's a latch on the front that allows the hinged top to be popped open for easy cleaning. After shaving, you just push this button and run hot water inside the hair collection chamber and under the blades. Then you just leave it open to air dry. On the back of the 8240 is the standard spring release trimmer for mustaches and sideburns.<br /><br />You can try the Philips Norelco 8240 risk-free for 45 days. If you're not fully satisfied after using this shaver exclusively for three weeks, you can send it back to Philips Norelco for a refund--but it must be shipped prepaid by insured mail. So you really have nothing to lose but the cost of shipping. As far as I'm concerned, this is the best electric razor I've ever used. But, if you've got the extra cash, you might want to go for the higher grade 8250 or 8251 model.<br /><br />\\"WARNING: Close supervision is necessary when this razor is used by children.\\"t be shipped prepaid by insured mail. So you really have nothing to lose but the cost of shipping. As far as I'm concerned, this is the best electric razor I've ever used. But, if you've got the extra cash, you might want to go for the higher grade 8250 or 8251 model. \\"WARNING: Close supervision is necessary when this razor is used by children.\\"
  362. Well I received this razor from Amazon.com in immaculate condition. I have never used an electric razor prior to this one and all I can say is electric shaving is a great alternative. This unit is light-weight, holds a charge for weeks, and is simple to maintain. I simply turn the unit on and run the razor over my face in small circular motions and voila! smooth clean skin free of any hairs. The unit cleans easily under running water and apparently, the blades are antimicrobial! Now with all the rules and regulations for airline flights, an electric razor will prevent some of the headaches while traveling. Plus since this unit holds a charge for weeks, you can leave the charger at home. As for the flip-up trimmer, I have only used it once on my sideburns and found it difficult to use since it is hard to see where the blades will make contact. I'm sure with some practice it will become easier. This is a wonderful razor and I'm glad I got it!
